description: The Microsoft Technology Associate (MTA) validates building-block technology concepts and helps students explore, discover and pursue successful careers in Information Technology (IT) in an exciting and rewarding way! As the first step in the Microsoft Technology Certification Series, this new, entry-level certification provides students with confidence, credibility, and differentiation while focusing on basic terminology, and concepts like CIA Triad, which is a set of core security principles that can provide as the foundation for security. To gain an MTA certification, you must pass only one MTA exam.
name: MTA - Security Fundamentals - 98-367
subtitle: Security Fundamentals

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike introduce you to some of the core security principles and practices that anyone looking to get into IT should be familiar with. Here they specifically discuss the CIA triad; Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability.
episodes.title: Core Security Principles

In this episode,

Daniel, we're gonna be focusing in

17

18

you do need to understand a nice

20

21

You go to any company anywhere, and you'll
realize that even down to the secretaries

22
00:01:05.770 --> 00:01:09.370
or the people in HR, the people in

23
00:01:09.370 --> 00:01:11.920
You gotta know a little something
about security cuz we're all kind of

24

involved in that.

25

If I'm giving out my password to
everybody and their brother, well,

26

27

So today, Mike, you're gonna help us out,
sort of help fill in that gap,

28
00:01:22.690 --> 00:01:25.500
give us that foundational knowledge so
that we understand security,

29

what we need to know, and especially
if you do want to get in security

30

this is definitely the stuff
you gotta know, right?

31
00:01:31.260 --> 00:01:32.240
>> It is, it is.

32
00:01:32.240 --> 00:01:35.180
And it's exciting stuff, so
why wouldn't you wanna get into this?

33
00:01:35.180 --> 00:01:37.900
All right, so let's start with
some basic terminology and

34
00:01:37.900 --> 00:01:42.930
a very core concept when it comes to
security, and that is the CIA triad.

35
00:01:42.930 --> 00:01:45.470
It doesn't matter where you go,
what webpage you visit,

36
00:01:45.470 --> 00:01:50.090
what book you read, you're gonna
see this term, CIA or CIA triad,

37
00:01:50.090 --> 00:01:53.760
and we're not talking about the Central
Intelligence Agency here in the US.

38
00:01:53.760 --> 00:01:55.122
>> Which is Triads.

39
00:01:55.122 --> 00:01:57.109
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Or more than Triads.

40
00:01:57.109 --> 00:01:57.929
>> That's right.

41
00:01:57.929 --> 00:01:59.560
[LAUGH]
>> We're going to some sort of

42
00:01:59.560 --> 00:02:00.902
secret court, aren't we, Mike?

43
00:02:00.902 --> 00:02:02.956
>> [LAUGH] We are in trouble, aren't we?

44
00:02:02.956 --> 00:02:08.940
All right, but CIA means confidentiality,
integrity, and availability.

45
00:02:08.940 --> 00:02:13.680
These are the three core security
principles that we have to follow.

46
00:02:13.680 --> 00:02:16.560
They really make the foundation
of our security,

47
00:02:16.560 --> 00:02:18.450
you can think of them as legs on a tripod.

48
00:02:18.450 --> 00:02:21.830
Without one of them the whole
thing is gonna fall over.

49
00:02:21.830 --> 00:02:25.470
So confidentiality,
integrity, and availability.

50
00:02:25.470 --> 00:02:26.960
When we're trying to secure a system,

51
00:02:26.960 --> 00:02:30.250
when we're trying to secure a network,
whatever it is.

52
00:02:30.250 --> 00:02:31.870
These are what we have to keep in mind.

53
00:02:31.870 --> 00:02:36.087
This is what we're trying to provide for
my systems and my network.

54
00:02:36.087 --> 00:02:39.140
Confidentiality, integrity,
and availability.

55
00:02:39.140 --> 00:02:42.780
And let's start with the first one,
confidentiality, right?

56
00:02:42.780 --> 00:02:45.550
Confidentiality simply means

57
00:02:45.550 --> 00:02:49.790
only authorized people should
have access to that information.

58
00:02:49.790 --> 00:02:50.340
Right?

59
00:02:50.340 --> 00:02:55.030
If it's something confidential between
you and your doctor then only you and

60
00:02:55.030 --> 00:02:58.160
your doctor should have access
to the information, right?

61
00:02:58.160 --> 00:02:59.070
The janitor that comes and

62
00:02:59.070 --> 00:03:02.160
cleans the place shouldn't have
access to the information.

63
00:03:02.160 --> 00:03:04.051
The guy that's coming
in to fix the phones or

64
00:03:04.051 --> 00:03:07.186
coming in to fix the network shouldn't
have access to the information.

65
00:03:07.186 --> 00:03:08.600
It's confidential.

66
00:03:08.600 --> 00:03:11.200
You might have information
at a workplace where

67
00:03:11.200 --> 00:03:14.360
all of the employees have access to it,
it's our employee handbook.

68
00:03:14.360 --> 00:03:14.870
Right?

69
00:03:14.870 --> 00:03:18.640
But nobody outside the organization
should have access to that information.

70
00:03:18.640 --> 00:03:19.600
So it's confidential.

71
00:03:19.600 --> 00:03:22.560
So when you think of confidential,
don't think super secret.

72
00:03:22.560 --> 00:03:24.390
That's not necessarily the case.

73
00:03:24.390 --> 00:03:26.940
But there is some level of
control that I wanna provide.

74
00:03:26.940 --> 00:03:29.350
Not everybody should have access to it.

75
00:03:29.350 --> 00:03:32.810
There is information that's available to
the public and that anybody can have,

76
00:03:32.810 --> 00:03:36.210
right, like my website information
that the public can come to.

77
00:03:36.210 --> 00:03:37.560
Well, that's not confidential.

78
00:03:37.560 --> 00:03:40.040
There's no level of confidentiality there.

79
00:03:40.040 --> 00:03:45.050
But on most of our documents we're gonna
provide some level of confidentiality.

80
00:03:45.050 --> 00:03:46.670
Now how do we do that?

81
00:03:46.670 --> 00:03:51.550
Well, we got several different methods
we can use to provide confidentiality.

82
00:03:51.550 --> 00:03:56.020
The one we always think of I think that
pops in everybodys mind is gonna be

83
00:03:56.020 --> 00:03:59.230
Encryption, because encryption
is a good way to make sure

84
00:03:59.230 --> 00:04:02.880
that only authorized users or
people have access to that information.

85
00:04:04.020 --> 00:04:06.710
Now Windows gives us a method
we can use to encrypt it.

86
00:04:06.710 --> 00:04:10.300
Part of the NTFS file system is EFS, or

87
00:04:10.300 --> 00:04:13.920
my encrypting file system and
let's take a look at how that works.

88
00:04:13.920 --> 00:04:18.520
I've got a Windows 7 box pulled up here,
I'm gonna open up file explorer, and

89
00:04:18.520 --> 00:04:22.920
I'm gonna navigate my way into the hard
drive and in this docs folder and

90
00:04:22.920 --> 00:04:24.555
here a file called Mike's stuff.

91
00:04:24.555 --> 00:04:25.935
Right?
This is my stuff,

92
00:04:25.935 --> 00:04:30.615
I don't want anybody else to be
able to access this information.

93
00:04:30.615 --> 00:04:31.315
So, what do I do?

94
00:04:31.315 --> 00:04:35.755
Well, I can right click on it,
and I can pull up the properties.

95
00:04:36.910 --> 00:04:40.561
I can go over to the Advanced Attributes,
and

96
00:04:40.561 --> 00:04:44.510
I can choose to encrypt
contents to secure data.

97
00:04:44.510 --> 00:04:47.728
I'll click OK, and I'll click OK.

98
00:04:47.728 --> 00:04:53.200
And I'm gonna do the file only, click OK,
and notice the file name turned green.

99
00:04:53.200 --> 00:04:57.390
This is Windows's visual cue that
this file has been encrypted.

100
00:04:57.390 --> 00:05:01.850
Now, to me, because I'm the one that
encrypted it, I'm an authorized user.

101
00:05:01.850 --> 00:05:06.380
So I can double-click on it,
I can open it, I can type in there.

102
00:05:06.380 --> 00:05:13.000
And I can make changes to it,
I can save it, I can close it.

103
00:05:13.000 --> 00:05:14.270
I don't have to do anything.

104
00:05:14.270 --> 00:05:17.120
To me, the document didn't seem encrypted,
right?

105
00:05:17.120 --> 00:05:20.380
I double click on it like normal,
it just opens right up.

106
00:05:20.380 --> 00:05:25.420
Well let's see what happens if
we try that with somebody else.

107
00:05:25.420 --> 00:05:26.520
And we'll log off.

108
00:05:29.060 --> 00:05:34.430
And I'm gonna log back on as a different
user, a little switch user, other user.

109
00:05:35.990 --> 00:05:38.440
And, Daniel, if you can just give
me your password real quick?

110
00:05:38.440 --> 00:05:41.180
>> Oh yeah, it's not gonna happen.

111
00:05:41.180 --> 00:05:42.380
>> Not.

112
00:05:42.380 --> 00:05:43.395
>> Yeah, oh crap.

113
00:05:43.395 --> 00:05:44.640
[LAUGH]
>> Gonna, happen.

114
00:05:44.640 --> 00:05:45.625
Let's see if that worked.

115
00:05:45.625 --> 00:05:47.836
>> [LAUGH] Outlook did not work.

116
00:05:47.836 --> 00:05:49.870
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] All right, so

117
00:05:49.870 --> 00:05:51.580
now I'm logged on as Daniel.

118
00:05:51.580 --> 00:05:58.280
I open up File Explorer, I navigate into
that same location, and there's my stuff.

119
00:05:58.280 --> 00:05:59.120
I can see it's green,

120
00:05:59.120 --> 00:06:04.390
I can see the file, I double click on it,
I get the old, access is denied.

121
00:06:04.390 --> 00:06:07.900
So there's an example of how
encryption can provide us

122
00:06:07.900 --> 00:06:09.650
with a level of confidentiality.

123
00:06:09.650 --> 00:06:12.970
If you're not authorized to get in that
document, you're not gonna get it.

124
00:06:12.970 --> 00:06:16.512
>> And Mike, even if somehow I
did grab a copy of this document,

125
00:06:16.512 --> 00:06:19.228
its not gonna show me
the information inside.

126
00:06:19.228 --> 00:06:21.860
Its just gonna be a bunch of
garbage as far I'm concerned.

127
00:06:21.860 --> 00:06:22.410
>> Absolutely.

128
00:06:22.410 --> 00:06:26.360
In fact, you're gonna have a hard time
getting it because this particular

129
00:06:26.360 --> 00:06:28.750
encryption is a part of the file system.

130
00:06:28.750 --> 00:06:31.280
So let's say Daniel wanted to copy
that over to a thumb drive and

131
00:06:31.280 --> 00:06:33.480
take it with him and try to break into it.

132
00:06:33.480 --> 00:06:37.950
Well that thumb drive unless it's formated
in DFS,and even if it is, he didn't have

133
00:06:37.950 --> 00:06:41.220
permission to decrypt it, it's got to be
decrypted, sent across the network, and

134
00:06:41.220 --> 00:06:45.430
then encrypted again on the file system,
he won't even be able to copy that

135
00:06:45.430 --> 00:06:48.390
file over to another volume or
a thumb drive or anything like that.

136
00:06:48.390 --> 00:06:51.950
So it really does give us that
level of confidentiality,

137
00:06:51.950 --> 00:06:53.190
which is a big part in security.

138
00:06:53.190 --> 00:06:55.860
You're gonna see encryption in just about

139
00:06:55.860 --> 00:07:00.940
every place you go to because it is a easy
way to provide that confidentiality.

140
00:07:00.940 --> 00:07:04.520
Now, we get into advanced security classes
we're gonna learn that we've got to be

141
00:07:04.520 --> 00:07:07.390
careful with that because
the way encryption works,

142
00:07:07.390 --> 00:07:12.740
it uses keys along with mathematical
formulas to encrypt that information.

143
00:07:12.740 --> 00:07:13.950
The problem is,

144
00:07:13.950 --> 00:07:18.310
if I ever lose those keys not even I would
be able to get back in to that document.

145
00:07:18.310 --> 00:07:21.470
So there are methods that we've got
to take place to ensure that we don't

146
00:07:21.470 --> 00:07:24.060
permanently lose access
to that information, but

147
00:07:24.060 --> 00:07:27.600
that's in a next level
of security classes.

148
00:07:27.600 --> 00:07:28.640
So we've got encryption.

149
00:07:28.640 --> 00:07:31.230
That's a very common way to
provide that confidentiality.

150
00:07:31.230 --> 00:07:33.870
Like I said, it's the one that I
think everybody thinks of when they

151
00:07:33.870 --> 00:07:37.290
first think of confidentiality,
but it's not the only method.

152
00:07:37.290 --> 00:07:40.107
Other methods would
include authentication.

153
00:07:40.107 --> 00:07:40.790
Right?

154
00:07:40.790 --> 00:07:42.770
If you can't log onto the system,

155
00:07:42.770 --> 00:07:45.993
then you're not gonna get
access to that information.

156
00:07:45.993 --> 00:07:51.459
So using a good strong authentication
method is a big part in confidentiality.

157
00:07:51.459 --> 00:07:52.018
Right.

158
00:07:52.018 --> 00:07:57.319
In Windows for example, we have password
policies that make sure I can enforce

159
00:07:57.319 --> 00:08:02.321
the types of passwords, how often I
have to change it, things like that.

160
00:08:02.321 --> 00:08:04.950
In fact, let's take a peek at it.

161
00:08:04.950 --> 00:08:07.697
If I come over here to
my domain controller,

162
00:08:07.697 --> 00:08:10.830
I can open up my group
policy management console.

163
00:08:12.040 --> 00:08:17.780
Pull up my Default Domain Policy,
expand out Policies, Windows Settings,

164
00:08:17.780 --> 00:08:23.930
Security Settings, Account Policies,
and there is my Password Policy.

165
00:08:23.930 --> 00:08:26.480
And in a domain environment by default

166
00:08:26.480 --> 00:08:30.280
they're doing things like you have to
change your password every 42 days.

167
00:08:30.280 --> 00:08:33.580
I'll remember the last 24
passwords that you've used, so

168
00:08:33.580 --> 00:08:36.450
you can't reuse the same password over and
over again.

169
00:08:36.450 --> 00:08:39.020
It has to be at least
seven characters long.

170
00:08:39.020 --> 00:08:42.220
Has to meet complexity requirements,
meaning it has to be

171
00:08:42.220 --> 00:08:46.670
made up of a combination of characters,
not just letters, not just numbers.

172
00:08:46.670 --> 00:08:50.540
So these are things that I can do
to make sure we're using a good,

173
00:08:50.540 --> 00:08:52.350
strong authentication method.

174
00:08:52.350 --> 00:08:53.580
Not the only place.

175
00:08:53.580 --> 00:08:55.120
If you have a website, right?

176
00:08:55.120 --> 00:08:58.710
A lot of websites if you want
somebody log into that website,

177
00:08:58.710 --> 00:09:00.230
how are you going to authenticate that?

178
00:09:00.230 --> 00:09:04.200
You could do very simple forms based
authentication, or we could go much

179
00:09:04.200 --> 00:09:08.760
more complex with like active directive
federation services, and things like that.

180
00:09:08.760 --> 00:09:13.870
But we want to make sure that we are using
some good strong authentication method.

181
00:09:13.870 --> 00:09:16.540
Otherwise, somebody could
attempt at guess passwords,

182
00:09:16.540 --> 00:09:19.190
or try to break that authentication, and

183
00:09:19.190 --> 00:09:22.990
get access to information that
they should not have access to.

184
00:09:22.990 --> 00:09:28.150
Another method we can use to provide
confidentiality is going to be

185
00:09:28.150 --> 00:09:32.920
access control, and
access control is using, in Windows,

186
00:09:32.920 --> 00:09:37.200
that's going be access control list,
part of my NTFS file system.

187
00:09:37.200 --> 00:09:41.270
Now let me go back over here, for
example, and take a look at a document.

188
00:09:41.270 --> 00:09:43.760
I'm still logged in as Daniel.

189
00:09:43.760 --> 00:09:45.540
So let's see if Daniel's
going to have permissions.

190
00:09:45.540 --> 00:09:46.340
He's not.

191
00:09:46.340 --> 00:09:47.910
I just know he's not.

192
00:09:47.910 --> 00:09:49.170
I didn't give Daniel any permissions.

193
00:09:49.170 --> 00:09:51.070
I don't trust the guy.

194
00:09:51.070 --> 00:09:52.425
>> He's a shady character that Daniel.

195
00:09:52.425 --> 00:09:55.288
[LAUGH]
>> He is a little bit shady.

196
00:09:55.288 --> 00:09:58.847
So I'm going to do a little switch user,
other user, and

197
00:09:58.847 --> 00:10:01.006
log back on as the administrator.

198
00:10:04.356 --> 00:10:06.410
So I will have permissions
to show you this.

199
00:10:06.410 --> 00:10:08.760
And once you get logged in,
I'm going to open up File Explorer.

200
00:10:08.760 --> 00:10:12.340
And again, access control,
as far as the confidentiality goes,

201
00:10:12.340 --> 00:10:15.630
is preventing people to be
able to access the resource.

202
00:10:15.630 --> 00:10:18.980
If you can't access the resource, then
you can't see the information inside it.

203
00:10:18.980 --> 00:10:23.220
So I am providing a level
of confidentiality.

204
00:10:24.470 --> 00:10:28.930
If I go take a look back over here,
at that folder.

205
00:10:28.930 --> 00:10:30.150
Here's my handbook.

206
00:10:30.150 --> 00:10:30.650
Oops.

207
00:10:32.060 --> 00:10:38.200
And if I pull up the properties for
this handbook, I go to that Security tab,

208
00:10:39.490 --> 00:10:45.620
I'll see that the hosts have read
users have read and execute.

209
00:10:45.620 --> 00:10:48.390
Let's say this was just for
hosts all right, and

210
00:10:48.390 --> 00:10:51.100
they didn't want anybody
else being able to see it.

211
00:10:51.100 --> 00:10:52.590
Well, I could remove users.

212
00:10:52.590 --> 00:10:55.560
I'll click edit,
I'll grab those users, and

213
00:10:55.560 --> 00:10:59.160
I'll remove their permissions and
I'll apply that change.

214
00:10:59.160 --> 00:10:59.820
Right.

215
00:10:59.820 --> 00:11:05.900
So, by using that access control list,
I am in control of who has access in

216
00:11:05.900 --> 00:11:10.780
the first place and what level of access
they have, whether they can just read, or

217
00:11:10.780 --> 00:11:16.380
read and write, or modify, or
full control or whatever the case may be.

218
00:11:16.380 --> 00:11:20.150
So three different ways I can really
provide for that confidentiality,

219
00:11:20.150 --> 00:11:25.690
encryption, I can use access control
lists, and I can do authentication.

220
00:11:25.690 --> 00:11:27.350
All three provide that confidentiality.

221
00:11:27.350 --> 00:11:32.520
All right, next thing on our CA triad,
that is integrity.

222
00:11:32.520 --> 00:11:35.530
And integrity means when it
comes to your computers and

223
00:11:35.530 --> 00:11:39.000
keeping our information secure,
we talked about integrity,

224
00:11:39.000 --> 00:11:43.663
we're talking about the ability to prevent
unauthorized changes to information.

225
00:11:43.663 --> 00:11:50.150
I need to make sure that this document
does not get modified unintentionally.

226
00:11:50.150 --> 00:11:54.400
Intentional changes, if you're supposed
to be able to make changes, that's okay.

227

00:24:01.252 --> 00:24:03.415
comes through and floods my building and

461
00:24:03.415 --> 00:24:06.869
my server closet's under water
my data is no longer available.

462
00:24:06.869 --> 00:24:10.552
So there can be different natural
disasters obviously in different areas of

463
00:24:10.552 --> 00:24:14.533
the world that we have to deal with, but
something that we've got to think about.

464
00:24:14.533 --> 00:24:15.745
>> Right.
>> I've gotta make sure that

465
00:24:15.745 --> 00:24:16.520
data's available.

466
00:24:16.520 --> 00:24:19.660
Whether that means maybe
having a cold site or

467
00:24:19.660 --> 00:24:24.920
a hot site somewhere else that's outside
of that natural disaster occurrence area.

468
00:24:24.920 --> 00:24:26.870
So that if something happens I can move.

469
00:24:26.870 --> 00:24:30.380
Having offsite backups,
putting stuff up in the Cloud.

470
00:24:30.380 --> 00:24:34.530
All of these can help me
provide that availability.

471
00:24:35.970 --> 00:24:37.270
But they can be deliberate.

472
00:24:37.270 --> 00:24:38.510
I say they can be accidental.

473
00:24:38.510 --> 00:24:41.870
It could be, like I said,
somebody runs into a light post and

474
00:24:41.870 --> 00:24:45.010
takes out the power from my building or
what have you.

475
00:24:45.010 --> 00:24:46.400
But it can also be deliberate.

476
00:24:46.400 --> 00:24:48.630
Could be bad guys doing as
Daniel was saying earlier,

477
00:24:48.630 --> 00:24:51.500
a denial of service on our web server.

478
00:24:51.500 --> 00:24:55.415
Whether if they can send so much data to
my web server that my web server can no

479
00:24:55.415 --> 00:24:58.950
longer respond to requests,
well now I can't sell my product.

480
00:24:58.950 --> 00:25:01.330
My customers can't get to my website.

481
00:25:01.330 --> 00:25:03.470
That's an availability issue.

482
00:25:03.470 --> 00:25:03.970
Right?

483
00:25:05.400 --> 00:25:08.910
There's several different attacks
that they can do to try to do what

484
00:25:08.910 --> 00:25:13.000
are called denial of service attacks,
all important.

485
00:25:13.000 --> 00:25:16.770
So, it is one of those things
that sometimes gets overlooked

486
00:25:16.770 --> 00:25:21.300
when it comes to security, but
availability again, a big part of it.

487
00:25:21.300 --> 00:25:22.720
We've gotta have em all.

488
00:25:22.720 --> 00:25:25.642
As I said at the very beginning,
the CIA triad.

489
00:25:25.642 --> 00:25:27.450
CIA triad.

490
00:25:27.450 --> 00:25:29.110
It's like a tripod.

491
00:25:29.110 --> 00:25:33.840
One of those legs is out or missing,
the whole thing's gonna fall over.

492
00:25:33.840 --> 00:25:36.830
And you gotta put equal
importance on each one.

493
00:25:36.830 --> 00:25:39.660
I like to think of the guy that's got
a tripod where one of the legs is shorter

494
00:25:39.660 --> 00:25:40.232
than the other.

495
00:25:40.232 --> 00:25:40.744
>> Tilty.
>> [LAUGH]

496
00:25:40.744 --> 00:25:42.550
>> Yeah, exactly.

497
00:25:42.550 --> 00:25:44.280
It's gonna work.

498
00:25:44.280 --> 00:25:46.839
We can make it work, but not-
>> It ain't gonna be pretty.

499
00:25:46.839 --> 00:25:49.182
>> [LAUGH] Or comfortable.

500
00:25:49.182 --> 00:25:51.590
[LAUGH]
>> So you've got to provide.

501
00:25:51.590 --> 00:25:56.440
You've got to make sure you're spending
due diligence or taking focus on all three

502
00:25:56.440 --> 00:26:00.570
of those areas there, confidentiality,
integrity, and availability.

503
00:26:00.570 --> 00:26:03.700
And these are really
the cornerstones of security.

504
00:26:03.700 --> 00:26:08.560
When you get into the security field and
when you go to secure a server, when

505
00:26:08.560 --> 00:26:12.760
you go to secure and individual machine,
when you go to secure the entire network,

506
00:26:12.760 --> 00:26:16.258
when you go to secure the enterprise,
these are the things you're looking at.

507
00:26:16.258 --> 00:26:17.130
And you wanna sit there and

508
00:26:17.130 --> 00:26:20.600
you want to think about how we're
gonna provide confidentiality?

509
00:26:20.600 --> 00:26:22.970
What is the best method?

510
00:26:22.970 --> 00:26:25.240
And not everything get's
the same level of protection.

511
00:26:25.240 --> 00:26:27.150
Right?
When it comes to confidentiality,

512
00:26:27.150 --> 00:26:29.190
you can categorize things.

513
00:26:29.190 --> 00:26:30.510
You might have some documents and

514
00:26:30.510 --> 00:26:33.180
some resources that the public
can get access to, right?

515
00:26:33.180 --> 00:26:34.100
Stuff on my website.

516
00:26:34.100 --> 00:26:36.340
I want them to see product descriptions.

517
00:26:36.340 --> 00:26:39.410
Pictures of the product that
they're thinking about ordering.

518
00:26:39.410 --> 00:26:43.030
Other information,
I need to keep a little more confidential.

519
00:26:43.030 --> 00:26:46.140
That's the employee handbook or
the employee phone list.

520
00:26:46.140 --> 00:26:47.270
And things like that, right?

521
00:26:47.270 --> 00:26:50.690
Everybody in the company, but
nobody outside of the company.

522
00:26:50.690 --> 00:26:54.580
Other things still might have a higher
level of security or confidentiality

523
00:26:54.580 --> 00:26:58.660
associated, those quarterly
reports on our profits and losses.

524
00:26:58.660 --> 00:27:02.740
As an employee I might have access to
them, but those c level employees do.

525
00:27:02.740 --> 00:27:04.064
All right?
My HR people might or

526
00:27:04.064 --> 00:27:08.110
my budgeting people or whomever,
they might have access to it.

527
00:27:08.110 --> 00:27:11.660
So different levels of confidentiality
that we've gotta be able to provide.

528
00:27:11.660 --> 00:27:13.180
How are we gonna implement that?

529
00:27:13.180 --> 00:27:16.730
What are we gonna use that'll
give me that level of control?

530
00:27:16.730 --> 00:27:18.650
So you'll go through and
you'll classify things.

531
00:27:18.650 --> 00:27:23.600
And you might make up your own system like
very confidential, somewhat confidential,

532
00:27:23.600 --> 00:27:25.460
and not confidential.

533
00:27:25.460 --> 00:27:30.248
Or you might go more of a military
thing and go top secret, confidential,

534
00:27:30.248 --> 00:27:34.840
in public, in private or what have you but
come up with some system for

535
00:27:34.840 --> 00:27:36.170
confidentiality.

536
00:27:36.170 --> 00:27:40.760
Availability again making sure that
that information is available.

537
00:27:40.760 --> 00:27:45.620
That means doing things like backups and
clustering, providing full

538
00:27:45.620 --> 00:27:50.570
tolerance and making sure that our other
security methods haven't gone too far.

539
00:27:50.570 --> 00:27:52.640
And then integrity and
I kind of went out of order there.

540
00:27:52.640 --> 00:27:56.410
But integrity, making sure that
those files aren't modified or

541
00:27:56.410 --> 00:28:02.160
that the resources are not modified or
at least giving me the ability to detect

542
00:28:02.160 --> 00:28:05.830
that there has been a change, whether
it was intentional or unintentional.

543
00:28:05.830 --> 00:28:07.720
So CIA triad.

544
00:28:07.720 --> 00:28:10.700
Confidentiality and
integrity and availability.

545
00:28:10.700 --> 00:28:11.580
>> I'll tell you Mike.

546
00:28:11.580 --> 00:28:15.130
You were talking about auditing earlier
when it came to integrity, and it really

547
00:28:15.130 --> 00:28:20.940
hit home to me, exactly how important it
is to not share your information, right?

548
00:28:20.940 --> 00:28:24.380
Because if he had my password,
my user name, what could he do?

549
00:28:24.380 --> 00:28:24.880
He could log in.

550
00:28:24.880 --> 00:28:26.660
He could make changes.

551
00:28:26.660 --> 00:28:30.550
Now when the system's administrators,
we go to see who made that change.

552
00:28:30.550 --> 00:28:34.160
Well if he logged in as me guess who's
gonna get the finger pointed at them.

553
00:28:34.160 --> 00:28:36.480
I am.
I used to yell at users all the time for

554
00:28:36.480 --> 00:28:37.650
sharing their data.

555
00:28:37.650 --> 00:28:42.790
Do not share your username and
password with anyone, keep those things on

556
00:28:42.790 --> 00:28:46.820
the QT as yours, because if anybody
goes in and they make a change or

557
00:28:46.820 --> 00:28:51.280
they delete something, and it's done under
your name, guess who we're gonna point to?

558
00:28:51.280 --> 00:28:55.090
And you would really have to come up
with some strong evidence to show

559
00:28:55.090 --> 00:28:56.030
that it wasn't you,

560
00:28:56.030 --> 00:29:00.380
because the computer is telling us that
it was you through that audit trail.

561
00:29:00.380 --> 00:29:03.150
>> Absolutely, you're gonna need a time
stamp picture from somewhere saying,

562
00:29:03.150 --> 00:29:05.110
I was not at that computer.

563
00:29:05.110 --> 00:29:08.030
And then you're still gonna get in
trouble because you gave your password

564
00:29:08.030 --> 00:29:09.800
to somebody and
now they're logged on as you.

565
00:29:09.800 --> 00:29:10.590
So, yeah.

566
00:29:10.590 --> 00:29:12.430
Don't do that.

567
00:29:12.430 --> 00:29:15.250
>> Well, Mike it looks like we're
running a little bit out of time and

568
00:29:15.250 --> 00:29:19.470
I know we have a lot more stuff to cover,
a lot of really good information, but

569
00:29:19.470 --> 00:29:21.730
that means we're gonna
have to do a part two.

570
00:29:21.730 --> 00:29:23.280
Hopefully we'll see you good people there.

571
00:29:23.280 --> 00:29:26.190
Mike, thanks for those demonstrations,
explanations that you gave us.

572
00:29:26.190 --> 00:29:27.410
Really, really helpful.

573
00:29:27.410 --> 00:29:30.730
We're gonna go on to that part two, as for
this episode, we're gonna go ahead and

574
00:29:30.730 --> 00:29:31.380
sign off.

575
00:29:31.380 --> 00:29:34.110
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

576
00:29:34.110 --> 00:29:34.960
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

577
00:29:34.960 --> 00:29:36.979
>> We'll see you next time.

578
00:29:36.979 --> 00:29:42.550

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue explaining core security principles moving into threat and risk assessment. They detail how to mitigate loss by creating a risk matrix and creating appropriate responses to those threats. Also discussed is the principal of least privilege, social engineering, and defining an attack surface.
episodes.title: Core Security Principles Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.643 --> 00:00:13.268
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:13.268 --> 00:00:16.680
Welcome to another exciting
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.680 --> 00:00:17.980
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:17.980 --> 00:00:20.960
Joining me again in the studio
is none other than Mike Rodrick.

6
00:00:20.960 --> 00:00:21.990
How's it going today, Mike?

7
00:00:21.990 --> 00:00:23.210
>> Oh, it's going great Daniel.

8
00:00:23.210 --> 00:00:24.810
I'm excited as always to be here.

9
00:00:24.810 --> 00:00:27.410
We've got our MTA content
coming your way and

10

in this one we're going to be focusing

11
00:00:32.310 --> 00:00:35.360
So if you missed the last episode,
make sure you go back and watch it.

12
00:00:35.360 --> 00:00:37.360
We're continuing on here.

13
00:00:37.360 --> 00:00:42.540
In the previous one we really went
over the basics of the CIA triad,

14
00:00:42.540 --> 00:00:46.620
confidentiality, integrity and
availability.

15
00:00:46.620 --> 00:00:50.400
We're gonna continue that thought process
with these core security principles.

16
00:00:50.400 --> 00:00:53.970
And now we're gonna start
talking about risk matrix,

17
00:00:53.970 --> 00:00:56.380
is the next thing on our list.

18
00:00:56.380 --> 00:01:00.510
And we talk about risk matrixes, or
risk in general, let's start there.

19
00:01:00.510 --> 00:01:04.650
A risk is the potential for
something to go wrong.

20
00:01:04.650 --> 00:01:07.130
That's a very layman's term of it, right?

21
00:01:07.130 --> 00:01:09.850
But when we look at our systems,

22
00:01:09.850 --> 00:01:14.660
we've gotta think about all of the things
that threaten those systems, right?

23
00:01:14.660 --> 00:01:16.400
Those are known as risks.

24
00:01:16.400 --> 00:01:18.390
And we have to list them all out.

25
00:01:18.390 --> 00:01:22.220
And then we start looking at,
what is the likelihood

26
00:01:22.220 --> 00:01:27.430
of each of these risks coming to fruition,
and we also have to think about

27
00:01:27.430 --> 00:01:32.220
what the impact of that risk would be,
if it did happen.

28
00:01:32.220 --> 00:01:33.910
So like for example here in Florida,

29
00:01:33.910 --> 00:01:37.760
we might think of things like well there's
the risk of a hurricane coming through.

30
00:01:37.760 --> 00:01:42.370
Well the likelihood of a hurricane
hitting our building where we are,

31
00:01:42.370 --> 00:01:43.790
maybe is not so great.

32
00:01:43.790 --> 00:01:46.390
I mean we're in Florida, so
it's going to be greater than say,

33
00:01:46.390 --> 00:01:48.050
somebody that was living
up in North Dakota, and

34
00:01:48.050 --> 00:01:51.650
they have a data center there and
they're doing their risk assessment.

35
00:01:51.650 --> 00:01:56.110
All right, so it is gonna be greater for
us here in Florida, but still might be not

36
00:01:56.110 --> 00:01:59.780
extremely likely, it's not like it
happens every year or every month.

37
00:01:59.780 --> 00:02:02.820
So we would put that in
its place on our list.

38
00:02:02.820 --> 00:02:06.515
And we have to think about
the impact that it might have.

39
00:02:06.515 --> 00:02:09.980
Well, if a hurricane does hit us and
comes right through Gainesville,

40
00:02:09.980 --> 00:02:14.730
Florida, we know we're gonna be without
power, we're gonna have flood damage.

41
00:02:14.730 --> 00:02:17.920
So, we're gonna have some
serious damage to contend with.

42
00:02:17.920 --> 00:02:21.510
Those are the kind of things that we
do when we look at risk assessment.

43
00:02:21.510 --> 00:02:25.858
And not just natural, I mean we have
to think about power failures, or

44
00:02:25.858 --> 00:02:28.744
a bad guy doing a data
breach on our web server.

45
00:02:28.744 --> 00:02:30.940
These are all risks that we have to face.

46
00:02:30.940 --> 00:02:32.190
You look at your file server.

47
00:02:32.190 --> 00:02:34.750
What are risks that we
have with our file server?

48
00:02:34.750 --> 00:02:36.124
Well, power.

49
00:02:36.124 --> 00:02:39.700
I could have a power failure, that file
server is not gonna do me any good.

50
00:02:39.700 --> 00:02:42.110
Hardware failures,
those are going to occur.

51
00:02:42.110 --> 00:02:44.580
What is the likelihood of
that hard drive failing?

52
00:02:44.580 --> 00:02:47.424
It's going to happen at some point, right.

53
00:02:47.424 --> 00:02:50.303
Data corruption could occur.

54
00:02:50.303 --> 00:02:53.340
Any of these things, so those are the
kinds of things we're talking about.

55
00:02:53.340 --> 00:02:57.870
And so,
risk assessment is really sitting down and

56
00:02:57.870 --> 00:03:02.500
going through all the different
things that put our data at risk.

57
00:03:02.500 --> 00:03:03.860
And it really depends
on what you're doing.

58
00:03:03.860 --> 00:03:06.130
You could be doing
a hardware risk assessment.

59
00:03:06.130 --> 00:03:07.520
Software risk assessment,

60
00:03:07.520 --> 00:03:11.180
your building, all of it has
to go through risk assessment.

61
00:03:11.180 --> 00:03:15.369
And we list all that out, and
then we start putting it together in some

62
00:03:15.369 --> 00:03:20.330
meaningful fashion, and that's where
the risk matrix comes into play.

63
00:03:20.330 --> 00:03:22.630
So your risk assessment
is your evaluation.

64
00:03:23.660 --> 00:03:27.950
I mean, there's the risk that I
could get hit by a bus tomorrow and

65
00:03:27.950 --> 00:03:29.660
I might not make it into work.

66
00:03:29.660 --> 00:03:32.210
And so
the impact of that would be Daniel's

67
00:03:32.210 --> 00:03:36.200
gonna be standing here all alone going,
so Michael, what do we got for today?

68
00:03:36.200 --> 00:03:37.780
And he's not gonna get much of a response.

69
00:03:37.780 --> 00:03:38.823
>> That's about normal, right?

70
00:03:38.823 --> 00:03:43.770
>> [LAUGH] [CROSSTALK]
>> I kid the Mike, it's fun to do.

71
00:03:43.770 --> 00:03:45.110
But he's exactly right.

72
00:03:45.110 --> 00:03:50.024
We gotta kind of go through what we think
are very probable to least probable

73
00:03:50.024 --> 00:03:53.480
threats to our business and
our continuity.

74
00:03:53.480 --> 00:03:56.490
And figure out, what do we do in
case that kind of thing happens?

75
00:03:56.490 --> 00:03:57.590
Are we safe?

76
00:03:57.590 --> 00:04:02.720
Can we survive a complete data
loss on our main systems?

77
00:04:02.720 --> 00:04:04.000
Is that a possibility?

78
00:04:04.000 --> 00:04:09.040
When Mike's talking about risk assessment,
that spectrum varies very, very widely.

79
00:04:09.040 --> 00:04:12.660
You could really be a full time job just
sitting around, trying to figure out,

80
00:04:12.660 --> 00:04:16.590
okay, well here's what this
company has as far as assets go.

81
00:04:16.590 --> 00:04:20.470
Here are the threats to those assets and
here's how we can mitigate those assets,

82
00:04:20.470 --> 00:04:23.098
and that's basically what we're doing when
you're talking the risk major, correct?

83
00:04:23.098 --> 00:04:24.910
>> Yeah, absolutely, and Daniel puts it so

84
00:04:24.910 --> 00:04:28.100
well that it's going to vary
in situation to situation.

85
00:04:28.100 --> 00:04:31.470
If I'm a business and I've got a website
that's just informational, tells you about

86
00:04:31.470 --> 00:04:34.820
my company, it tells you where we're
physically located, and it's got some

87
00:04:34.820 --> 00:04:40.340
phone numbers on there that you could use
to contact us or whatever, and that's it.

88
00:04:40.340 --> 00:04:44.050
Well, if that web server goes down,
my business is still functioning, right.

89
00:04:44.050 --> 00:04:47.440
Maybe we're a brick and mortar store and
that's more about advertising and

90
00:04:47.440 --> 00:04:49.400
getting some kind of online presence.

91
00:04:49.400 --> 00:04:51.190
If I'm Amazon, however, and

92
00:04:51.190 --> 00:04:55.350
my web servers are unavailable,
it's gonna cost me big bucks, right.

93
00:04:55.350 --> 00:04:59.090
So they're gonna put more effort into
protecting those web servers than

94
00:04:59.090 --> 00:05:00.520
that first business I used.

95
00:05:00.520 --> 00:05:04.210
And we're not gonna spend a lot of money
protecting those resources because

96
00:05:04.210 --> 00:05:06.350
the impact is not that great.

97
00:05:06.350 --> 00:05:10.460
So being able to sit down and
go over all those risks, and

98
00:05:10.460 --> 00:05:14.450
the threats that face those risks, and

99
00:05:14.450 --> 00:05:19.370
the likelihood and the impact,
that's what risk assessment is all about.

100
00:05:19.370 --> 00:05:22.906
When we start dumping it into a matrix,
and

101
00:05:22.906 --> 00:05:26.159
matrix is just a fancy word for a chart.

102
00:05:26.159 --> 00:05:28.682
When we start doing it,
when we're putting it in our charts,

103
00:05:28.682 --> 00:05:30.779
we can do it a couple of different ways,
all right.

104
00:05:30.779 --> 00:05:33.876
We can do what we call
qualitative analysis or

105
00:05:33.876 --> 00:05:36.570
we can do quantitative risk analysis.

106
00:05:37.590 --> 00:05:38.870
And both of them have their place.

107
00:05:38.870 --> 00:05:41.460
And sometimes we combine them or
sometimes we do both.

108
00:05:41.460 --> 00:05:46.630
But we do a qualitative,
we're really using very general terms.

109
00:05:46.630 --> 00:05:52.230
Like when I say that the likelihood,
we might have a scale of rare,

110
00:05:52.230 --> 00:05:56.050
unlikely, possible, likely, certain.

111
00:05:56.050 --> 00:06:00.920
Right, and for our consequence
it could be very low, to low,

our attack surface.

00:29:57.652 --> 00:29:58.900
And then, our users.

568
00:30:00.190 --> 00:30:02.310
This goes right back to what we just said.

569
00:30:02.310 --> 00:30:07.830
User education because employees
are a big part of our tax surface.

570
00:30:07.830 --> 00:30:09.990
Human error is a very common one.

571
00:30:09.990 --> 00:30:12.580
And not just lower level employees,

572
00:30:12.580 --> 00:30:17.700
I'm talking about the C-level people,
I'm talking about our IT people.

573
00:30:17.700 --> 00:30:21.040
Hey, we got that server in, it's Friday
afternoon, I can't wait to unpack it,

574
00:30:21.040 --> 00:30:23.830
throw it in the closet, I'm gonna stick
it in there on the rack, plug it on,

575
00:30:23.830 --> 00:30:27.350
get an IP address,
we got our new server up and running.

576
00:30:27.350 --> 00:30:29.454
Oh, 5 o'clock, time to go.

577
00:30:29.454 --> 00:30:30.567
No, right?

578
00:30:30.567 --> 00:30:32.445
I mean,
now you've got this server that's exposed.

579
00:30:32.445 --> 00:30:36.085
You haven't done any hardening to it or
anything like that.

580
00:30:36.085 --> 00:30:41.155
Easy for us to just like it is my
non-technical employees, if you will.

581
00:30:41.155 --> 00:30:44.005
So human error, easy one.

582
00:30:44.005 --> 00:30:46.495
Misconfigure a firewall rule.

583
00:30:46.495 --> 00:30:51.655
And instead of an implicit deny, we end
up putting in implicit allow that says,

584
00:30:51.655 --> 00:30:53.400
hey, if it's not on the list, allow it.

585
00:30:54.510 --> 00:30:56.820
Easy to do, simple mistake.

586
00:30:56.820 --> 00:31:00.380
And you just blew a big hole in
the security on your network.

587
00:31:00.380 --> 00:31:03.790
So human error, a very real thing that we
have to deal with and then, of course,

588
00:31:03.790 --> 00:31:06.570
social engineering which I
think we've hashed enough.

589
00:31:06.570 --> 00:31:09.270
It comes back to user education.

590
00:31:09.270 --> 00:31:13.250
We always want to strive to
reduce our attack service.

591
00:31:13.250 --> 00:31:16.870
Anything that we add to our network that's
gonna increase that attack service,

592
00:31:16.870 --> 00:31:20.460
that's gonna be another avenue in, we
really gotta stop and take a look at, and

593
00:31:20.460 --> 00:31:24.440
make sure, one, we need it and two,
we know how to secure it properly.

594
00:31:24.440 --> 00:31:25.230
>> Awesome stuff, Mike.

595
00:31:25.230 --> 00:31:28.210
Obviously, security is a large,
lengthy topic.

596
00:31:28.210 --> 00:31:31.180
It's a little involved, but
just understanding those basics.

597
00:31:31.180 --> 00:31:31.720
In my opinion,

598
00:31:31.720 --> 00:31:35.350
you did a great job of showing us those
basic fundamental understandings.

599
00:31:35.350 --> 00:31:38.690
He's right, one of the major ways that
people get into systems is through

600
00:31:38.690 --> 00:31:41.715
just exploiting us and
our human fallibility.

601
00:31:41.715 --> 00:31:44.195
Our ignorance of a topic or
anything like that.

602
00:31:44.195 --> 00:31:45.715
They'll use that to their advantage,

603
00:31:45.715 --> 00:31:51.005
so that's why we try to really
hammer home user on education.

604
00:31:51.005 --> 00:31:55.798
Understanding even the basics of this
stuff will help you keep yourself out

605
00:31:55.798 --> 00:31:58.170
of the weeds and secure your system.

606
00:31:58.170 --> 00:32:01.430
Mike, is there anything else we need to
go over today when it comes to security?

607
00:32:01.430 --> 00:32:04.980
>> No, I think we've hit most of the core
principles that we need to be familiar

608
00:32:04.980 --> 00:32:07.010
with at least for this exam.

609
00:32:07.010 --> 00:32:10.210
And hopefully it got you curious and
you got out, you take this exam,

610
00:32:10.210 --> 00:32:14.110
you pass it, and then you dive a little
further in to the world of security.

611
00:32:14.110 --> 00:32:14.710
>> Awesome stuff.

612
00:32:14.710 --> 00:32:15.530
Well, thank you so much for

613
00:32:15.530 --> 00:32:19.040
those demonstrations and
those explanations of security.

614
00:32:19.040 --> 00:32:21.960
Hopefully, you guys out there
are now a little more hardened

615
00:32:21.960 --> 00:32:24.690
when it comes to your security measures,
or at least you know what to do.

616
00:32:24.690 --> 00:32:27.490
As for this episode though,
we need to go ahead and close it down.

617
00:32:27.490 --> 00:32:30.920
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

618
00:32:30.920 --> 00:32:31.590
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

619
00:32:31.590 --> 00:32:33.339
>> And we'll see you next time.

620
00:32:33.339 --> 00:32:39.900

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel explain the elements of proper physical security. Here they explain how to implement defense-in-depth, or layered security keeping your systems safe by creating many checkpoints that an intruder would need to bypass before gaining access. This includes things like external and internal site security, implementing locking mechanisms, and disabling local logon access.
episodes.title: Physical Security
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

2

All right, greetings everyone and welcome

4

5
00:00:21.010 --> 00:00:21.870
How's it going today, Mike?

6

>> Oh, it's going great Daniel.

7

8

We've got our MTA content coming your way.

9

This one, we're going to be
looking at physical security.

10
00:00:30.680 --> 00:00:35.450
It's a part of security that in the IT
world sometimes gets overlooked.

11
00:00:35.450 --> 00:00:38.176
>> That's right, we've got to hit the gym,
get strong be powerful for

12
00:00:38.176 --> 00:00:40.180
them people try to steal our stuff.

13
00:00:40.180 --> 00:00:42.780
Well, that would be funny and it is,

14
00:00:42.780 --> 00:00:45.230
Mike's laughing hysterically
like a hyena right now.

15
00:00:45.230 --> 00:00:47.990
[LAUGH] But that's not the kind of
physical security which we're talking

16
00:00:47.990 --> 00:00:51.150
about, we're talking about how
do we secure physical items?

17
00:00:51.150 --> 00:00:54.090
How do I secure my server
from something coming in and

18
00:00:54.090 --> 00:00:55.840
actually gaining physical access?

19
00:00:55.840 --> 00:00:59.650
Plugging in a disk or a keyboard or
a monitor and doing something to it.

20
00:00:59.650 --> 00:01:02.590
How do I physically secure
my laptop from being stolen?

21
00:01:02.590 --> 00:01:04.990
That's the kind of physical
security that we're talking about.

22
00:01:04.990 --> 00:01:09.110
And it does involve a little
bit of building up, but

23
00:01:09.110 --> 00:01:11.190
Mike's going to be the one to
show us all that stuff today.

24
00:01:11.190 --> 00:01:14.130
>> I am and thank God it's not actually
physical strength, because if you look at

25
00:01:14.130 --> 00:01:17.550
him and you look at me, it'd be like,
okay just take my server, it's okay.

26
00:01:17.550 --> 00:01:18.910
>> All your base are belong to us.

27
00:01:18.910 --> 00:01:19.655
>> That's right.

28
00:01:19.655 --> 00:01:24.100
[LAUGH] Now, physical security is
a very important part of security.

29
00:01:24.100 --> 00:01:25.890
It does tend to get overlooked sometimes,

30
00:01:25.890 --> 00:01:28.960
because we like to focus on
the electronic side of things.

31
00:01:28.960 --> 00:01:29.560
Right?

32
00:01:29.560 --> 00:01:32.430
Love to get in here and configure servers,
and configure firewalls, and

33
00:01:32.430 --> 00:01:35.180
configure access points, and
lock my network down, and

34
00:01:35.180 --> 00:01:38.460
harden my servers, and harden my clients,
and all that good stuff.

35
00:01:38.460 --> 00:01:39.510
Right?
Those are the things that we're

36
00:01:39.510 --> 00:01:40.580
trained to do.

37
00:01:40.580 --> 00:01:45.130
As IT people that's what we love to
try to do, keep those bad guys out.

38
00:01:45.130 --> 00:01:46.400
There's a problem.

39
00:01:46.400 --> 00:01:49.930
Physical security will trump all of that.

40
00:01:49.930 --> 00:01:51.660
And if you ever go out and
do a Google search for

41
00:01:51.660 --> 00:01:57.540
Microsoft ten immutable laws of security,
one of my favorite ones in there is,

42
00:01:57.540 --> 00:02:01.720
if I can touch your computer,
its no longer your computer.

43
00:02:01.720 --> 00:02:05.600
And its that simple, because if I
have physical access to the machine,

44
00:02:05.600 --> 00:02:09.890
there's too many things that I can try to
do to get access to that data on there.

45
00:02:09.890 --> 00:02:13.360
I can simply steal the hard drive and
try to take it with me.

46
00:02:13.360 --> 00:02:15.650
I can run some alternate OS.

47
00:02:15.650 --> 00:02:17.650
I can boot that server
up to something else.

48
00:02:17.650 --> 00:02:20.260
I could try to do that and
gain access to that system.

49
00:02:20.260 --> 00:02:23.100
There's just too many things I can do,
and it's almost impossible to

50
00:02:23.100 --> 00:02:27.150
keep somebody out if they have
physical access to that machine.

51
00:02:27.150 --> 00:02:30.520
Which is why physical security is so
important.

52
00:02:30.520 --> 00:02:33.310
And it's not just on our servers,
it's everything.

53
00:02:33.310 --> 00:02:37.710
So we're going to start at the very
beginning and kind of work our way in.

54
00:02:37.710 --> 00:02:41.700
A couple of key concepts that we need
to be familiar with when we talk about

55
00:02:41.700 --> 00:02:45.498
physical security, and these concepts
aren't limited to just physical security.

56
00:02:45.498 --> 00:02:48.400
You're going to see that we
will reuse these same terms

57
00:02:48.400 --> 00:02:53.060
later on when we do look at the side of
protecting our network where we get in and

58
00:02:53.060 --> 00:02:56.560
we harden things and
configure settings and things like that.

59
00:02:56.560 --> 00:03:00.640
[COUGH] Excuse me, but
It applies to the physical part as well.

60
00:03:00.640 --> 00:03:04.780
And the first one that I want to
mention is called defense in depth.

61
00:03:04.780 --> 00:03:08.870
All that means, is we're going to
have multiple layers of security.

62
00:03:08.870 --> 00:03:10.140
We never want to put,

63
00:03:10.140 --> 00:03:13.530
I use my mother's old saying you know,
put all your eggs in one basket.

64
00:03:13.530 --> 00:03:14.610
You don't want to do that,

65
00:03:14.610 --> 00:03:19.540
because if the bad guy can break through
that one layer of security, that's it.

66
00:03:19.540 --> 00:03:23.320
He's like the fox in the hen house now and
he's got the run of the place, right.

67
00:03:23.320 --> 00:03:27.330
All you had was that one gate trying to
keep him out, that's not going to cut it,

68
00:03:27.330 --> 00:03:32.230
so we want multiple layer, after layer,
after layer, after layer of security, so

69
00:03:32.230 --> 00:03:36.310
when that bad guy comes and tries to get
access to our networks, to our data,

70
00:03:36.310 --> 00:03:40.220
to our hardware, whatever the case may be,
he doesn't have an easy time,

71
00:03:40.220 --> 00:03:44.600
right you get two big advantages
from doing defense in depth.

72
00:03:44.600 --> 00:03:49.690
One is the fact that it
requires more skill.

73
00:03:49.690 --> 00:03:53.430
If I have many layers of security,
they might be able to get through

74
00:03:53.430 --> 00:03:56.100
that first layer,
because maybe they're really good at.

75
00:03:56.100 --> 00:03:58.410
Let's say we've got guards outside, right?

76
00:03:58.410 --> 00:04:00.530
And they're able to come in.

77
00:04:00.530 --> 00:04:01.560
They've got uniforms.

78
00:04:01.560 --> 00:04:04.700
They've got all the right paperwork
maybe they get past the guards.

79
00:04:04.700 --> 00:04:06.760
Well if that was my only layer, that's it.

80
00:04:06.760 --> 00:04:09.060
They're done.
They can do whatever they want right?

81
00:04:09.060 --> 00:04:12.645
But we got more guards inside, or
we got cameras, or we got locked doors.

82
00:04:12.645 --> 00:04:15.775
So now, not only do they have to
be good at faking out the guards,

83
00:04:15.775 --> 00:04:17.935
but they've got to be able to pick locks.

84
00:04:17.935 --> 00:04:20.035
So the more layers you have,

85
00:04:20.035 --> 00:04:23.600
the more skill its going to require
from the bad guy to get through.

86
00:04:23.600 --> 00:04:25.020
So that's a good thing, right.

87
00:04:25.020 --> 00:04:29.060
Maybe he doesn't have all the skills to
get through all of your layers of defense.

88
00:04:29.060 --> 00:04:33.990
The second big advantage of defense in
depth is the fact that we might detect it.

89
00:04:33.990 --> 00:04:38.580
At one of those layers, hopefully they
will trigger some alarm, or somebody will

90
00:04:38.580 --> 00:04:42.140
wise up and go, wait a second,
something's a little bit fishy here.

91
00:04:42.140 --> 00:04:44.220
Let's stop and take a closer look at this.

92
00:04:44.220 --> 00:04:48.910
Every layer that we have to go through is
a chance for us to stop and examine, and

93
00:04:48.910 --> 00:04:50.270
see what's going on and

94
00:04:50.270 --> 00:04:52.890
make sure that this is something
that should be happening.

95
00:04:52.890 --> 00:04:56.310
So you get some real big advantages
of doing that defence In depth.

96
00:04:57.570 --> 00:05:01.520
Now, it also depends on your level
of security that you require.

97
00:05:01.520 --> 00:05:06.790
I'm not saying that the SOHO or the
mom-and-pop shop is going to have guards

98
00:05:06.790 --> 00:05:10.970
with 50 cal machine guns mounted up
on top of the building waiting for

99
00:05:10.970 --> 00:05:12.780
people to come up and say,
who the heck are you?

100
00:05:12.780 --> 00:05:15.360
Stop or I'll fire, or
anything like that, right.

101
00:05:15.360 --> 00:05:18.960
It's going to depend on your
requirements for security.

102
00:05:18.960 --> 00:05:24.230
But we can still implement layers of
defenses in any type of environment.

103
00:05:24.230 --> 00:05:26.228
>> Can't wait to frequent
that establishment.

104
00:05:26.228 --> 00:05:26.810
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.
>> [LAUGH] You're

105
00:05:26.810 --> 00:05:29.780
greeted by a Ma deuce .50 cal.

106
00:05:29.780 --> 00:05:31.493
That will deter just about anyone,

107
00:05:31.493 --> 00:05:34.130
even the people that
legitimately want to shop there.

108
00:05:34.130 --> 00:05:38.490
>> Right, I lived in DC for a while, and
it was right after some of those things

109
00:05:38.490 --> 00:05:43.180
were happening up there, and I remember
the Pentagon all of a sudden had

110
00:05:44.550 --> 00:05:49.280
Humvees out there with 50 cals mounted on
top of them and soldiers sitting there.

111
00:05:49.280 --> 00:05:51.900
You could see that that level
of security had gone up,

112
00:05:51.900 --> 00:05:53.510
but again that was defense in depth.

113
00:05:53.510 --> 00:05:55.290
These were at the edge of the parking lot.

114
00:05:55.290 --> 00:05:59.370
You weren't even getting into the parking
lot without being stopped and

115
00:05:59.370 --> 00:06:00.070
checked, right?

116
00:06:00.070 --> 00:06:03.870
[COUGH] So defense in depth,
a very important process.

117
00:06:03.870 --> 00:06:05.770
Let's take a look at my screen here.

118
00:06:05.770 --> 00:06:09.590
And, I've got just a simple diagram that
willl kind of explain a little bit, or

119
00:06:09.590 --> 00:06:14.110
help us picture what I mean
by layers of security.

120
00:06:14.110 --> 00:06:17.330
You know, you've got your outer perimeter,
this is going to be your grounds.

121
00:06:17.330 --> 00:06:20.430
It's wherever your facilities are.

122
00:06:20.430 --> 00:06:24.560
Now if you're in a stand alone facility
and this would be your public grounds,

123
00:06:24.560 --> 00:06:26.690
your parking lot, things like that.

124
00:06:26.690 --> 00:06:29.150
If you're in a strip mall type shop or

125
00:06:29.150 --> 00:06:33.790
your shared space, you might not
have that same outer perimeter.

126
00:06:33.790 --> 00:06:36.160
If you were in a mall, for example.

127
00:06:36.160 --> 00:06:38.730
And your outer perimeter might
be the actual doors to the mall.

128
00:06:38.730 --> 00:06:41.470
And it might not be completely
under your control, but

129
00:06:41.470 --> 00:06:43.770
you still have your store
front that you have.

130
00:06:43.770 --> 00:06:48.390
But that outer perimeter, this is where we
put things like security cameras, right.

131
00:06:48.390 --> 00:06:50.840
So we've got visual surveillance
of what's going on.

132
00:06:51.860 --> 00:06:53.070
We've got fences.

133
00:06:53.070 --> 00:06:57.850
And again depending on the level
of security, it might be a simple,

134
00:06:57.850 --> 00:07:02.480
small fence that just kind of funnels
everybody through one entry point, or

135
00:07:02.480 --> 00:07:06.140
it could be an eight foot chain link
with razor wire up at the top of it.

136
00:07:06.140 --> 00:07:11.890
But we've got that perimeter that defines
our area and where our security begins.

137
00:07:11.890 --> 00:07:16.260
We might have guards that walk around
the perimeter occasionally, looking for

138
00:07:16.260 --> 00:07:19.480
places where people have tried to
break through our security and maybe,

139
00:07:19.480 --> 00:07:21.730
kind of holes in that chain link fence.

140
00:07:21.730 --> 00:07:22.320
Lights.

141
00:07:22.320 --> 00:07:25.450
People forget about this,
light is a huge deterrent right,

142
00:07:25.450 --> 00:07:28.360
because the bad guys,
they don't want to be seen.

143
00:07:28.360 --> 00:07:31.390
And if you've got good lighting
out there in the parking lot,

144
00:07:31.390 --> 00:07:34.260
you can help keep that area safe and
secure.

145
00:07:34.260 --> 00:07:35.740
And remember,

146
00:07:35.740 --> 00:07:39.990
we're protecting our data and
our equipment, as well as our personnel.

147
00:07:39.990 --> 00:07:43.490
Our personnel is a very valuable
asset in our organization.

148
00:07:43.490 --> 00:07:46.050
Without them,
our organization doesn't do much.

149
00:07:46.050 --> 00:07:49.050
So, things like lights and guards
not only protect our facilities, but

150
00:07:49.050 --> 00:07:50.530
they're protecting our personnel, as well.

151
00:07:50.530 --> 00:07:54.100
As they're walking out to the car,
I don't need somebody jumping out from

152
00:07:54.100 --> 00:07:57.990
behind a bush in a dark corner of the
parking lot, and snagging their laptop.

153
00:07:57.990 --> 00:07:58.498
Right?
Or

154
00:07:58.498 --> 00:08:01.959
something like that, so
we've got that outer perimeter.

155
00:08:01.959 --> 00:08:03.861
Now, behind that, we don't stop there.

156
00:08:03.861 --> 00:08:05.116
Right?

157
00:08:05.116 --> 00:08:07.357
Behind that we've got
our internal perimeter.

158
00:08:07.357 --> 00:08:09.636
This is, well when you talk
about the internal perimeter,

159
00:08:09.636 --> 00:08:11.651
we're usually talking
about the building itself.

160
00:08:11.651 --> 00:08:15.816
So that front door, and
then even inside that front door,

161
00:08:15.816 --> 00:08:20.746
the elevators, the doors to the offices,
cameras in the hallways,

162
00:08:20.746 --> 00:08:25.862
badge readers or RFIDs to get through
doorways, and things like that.

163
00:08:25.862 --> 00:08:28.382
So we've got that
internal perimeter there.

164
00:08:28.382 --> 00:08:30.700
You might have somebody sitting
at a front desk, right?

165
00:08:30.700 --> 00:08:31.620
You've got guards.

166
00:08:31.620 --> 00:08:34.460
You might have guards on the outer
perimeter doing that patrol,

167
00:08:34.460 --> 00:08:38.835
but you've got guards sitting at a desk,
that everybody has to check in at, right?

168
00:08:38.835 --> 00:08:40.090
They're right there in the front lobby.

169
00:08:41.760 --> 00:08:44.770
Smoke detectors might be another
thing that you would see in this

170
00:08:44.770 --> 00:08:46.280
internal perimeter.

00:31:33.430 --> 00:31:36.930

00:31:54.180 --> 00:31:57.110

00:31:57.110 --> 00:32:00.350

00:32:00.350 --> 00:32:02.650

00:32:02.650 --> 00:32:07.430
Denying things, it becomes a little
bit more difficult to administer.

622
00:32:07.430 --> 00:32:11.090
But if you want to make sure that somebody
can't log on locally at the machine,

623
00:32:11.090 --> 00:32:14.750
you can create a group, and put them in
that group, and then add that group here,

624
00:32:14.750 --> 00:32:16.370
and they won't be able to log on.

625
00:32:16.370 --> 00:32:19.340
No matter even if they get added to
the administrator's group later on.

626
00:32:19.340 --> 00:32:22.030
This will take precedence
over the allow logon.

627
00:32:22.030 --> 00:32:25.310
So if you're on both lists, or
groups you belong to are in both lists,

628
00:32:25.310 --> 00:32:27.750
the deny will override the allow and
you won't be able to log on.

629
00:32:27.750 --> 00:32:30.320
And again, that's just another
level of physical security,

630
00:32:30.320 --> 00:32:33.640
it keeps that employee from going, hey
look, somebody left the server door open.

631
00:32:33.640 --> 00:32:35.240
Let's go see what kind of
fun we can have in there.

632
00:32:35.240 --> 00:32:36.850
They won't be able to log on.

633
00:32:36.850 --> 00:32:37.350
Right?

634
00:32:37.350 --> 00:32:40.570
So, another important part
of physical security.

635
00:32:40.570 --> 00:32:44.240
And it's just one of those things,
that again, gets overlooked, but

636
00:32:44.240 --> 00:32:45.910
it's a very important part of security, so

637
00:32:45.910 --> 00:32:50.250
we've got to make sure that we're paying
attention to that physical security.

638
00:32:50.250 --> 00:32:53.640
>> Yes, yes, you don't want to just

639
00:32:53.640 --> 00:32:58.420

642
00:33:08.880 --> 00:33:10.650
No, no, no.
We have to look at it,

00:33:10.650 --> 00:33:14.320
almost kind of think of yourself

644
00:33:14.320 --> 00:33:19.270
This is spy craft 101 right, I want
see how if I wanted to grab this data

645
00:33:19.270 --> 00:33:22.060
physically, how would I go about this?

646
00:33:22.060 --> 00:33:26.260
And physical security really
you can not over look that.

00:33:26.260 --> 00:33:28.950
Mike, I think you've done
a great job of showing us of how

648
00:33:28.950 --> 00:33:33.420
really important that is,
to harden that area of our network up.

649
00:33:33.420 --> 00:33:34.120
>> Good deal, good deal.

650
00:33:34.120 --> 00:33:35.860
Yeah, it can't be stressed enough.

651
00:33:35.860 --> 00:33:39.550
Just one last example I'll also give you,
a high security example.

652
00:33:39.550 --> 00:33:42.430
I went down and did some work for
a local energy company.

653
00:33:42.430 --> 00:33:45.400
And this energy company

654
00:33:45.400 --> 00:33:48.660
I wasn't at the nuclear power plant,
but their systems were tied in.

655
00:33:48.660 --> 00:33:52.730
When I walked into that building, I had to
go up to the front desk and I had to get

656
00:33:52.730 --> 00:33:57.320

was working there who I was here to see.

00:33:57.320 --> 00:33:59.150
He said there's the elevator
bank over there,

658
00:33:59.150 --> 00:34:01.380
you're going to get on
elevator number two.

659
00:34:01.380 --> 00:34:02.130
It was kind of odd.

660
00:34:02.130 --> 00:34:05.750
I walk over there and there's three
elevators, no buttons, right.

661
00:34:05.750 --> 00:34:09.920
He called the elevator and number two
comes down and the doors open up.

662
00:34:09.920 --> 00:34:13.770
I get on there and the doors close and
again, there's no buttons.

663
00:34:13.770 --> 00:34:17.330
And he sends it up to the floor

664
00:34:17.330 --> 00:34:20.340
I get off the elevator,
there's another set of glass doors.

665
00:34:20.340 --> 00:34:21.650
The elevator's closing behind me,

666
00:34:21.650 --> 00:34:24.240
and there's the set of

00:34:25.440 --> 00:34:29.730
I can't get back down the elevator

669
00:34:29.730 --> 00:34:31.060
These are the kind of things that,

670
00:34:31.060 --> 00:34:34.660
when you talk about physical security,
this is what we're referring to.

671
00:34:34.660 --> 00:34:35.570
>> That's right.

672
00:34:35.570 --> 00:34:37.430
All right, everyone,
looks like we've come to the end of yet

00:34:37.430 --> 00:34:39.820
another great episode here at ITProTV.

674
00:34:39.820 --> 00:34:40.770
Thanks for watching.

675

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike detail how to stay secure when connecting to the internet. Here they show you how to use settings in Internet Explorer that can increase your security; things like cookies settings, privacy settings, and pop-up blockers. They also show you how to use zones to apply specific settings to specific sites. Lastly they explain how websites can be secured using certificates and the Secure Sockets Layer(SSL) protocol.

how should I say this, they can be

00:02:34.370 --> 00:02:37.660
Those first define what the heck

45
00:02:37.660 --> 00:02:43.810

46
00:02:43.810 --> 00:02:48.080

00:03:13.760 --> 00:03:17.860

00:03:17.860 --> 00:03:22.330

00:03:22.330 --> 00:03:26.090
That's what makes it individual to me

00:03:26.090 --> 00:03:27.870

00:03:38.530 --> 00:03:41.430
But a lot of personally

00:03:42.980 --> 00:03:45.520
And like I said,
they can be beneficial, but

On the privacy tab, there's this

And you'll see the different

00:05:49.650 --> 00:05:50.930
So that would be a third party.

00:05:50.930 --> 00:05:53.520
Somebody that I didn't

00:05:53.520 --> 00:05:54.960

105
00:05:56.080 --> 00:06:00.320
Go down a little but further, kind of same

I go down a little bit further and

00:06:30.930 --> 00:06:34.495

third-party cookies that are going to

00:06:39.540 --> 00:06:42.330

00:06:43.430 --> 00:06:45.390

00:06:45.390 --> 00:06:48.860

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel explain the basics of user authentication. Here they talk about the different ways in which we can authenticate, such as something you know like a password, something you have, like a smart card, or something you are like your fingerprint. They also talk about the different places and methods that authentication may be occurring; locally, remotely, or at the domain level. Also covered is certificates and PKI or Public Key Infrastructure.

Because, the issuing party, the State
of Florida, put their stamp on it.

603
00:30:35.430 --> 00:30:39.330
They say, we've already verified all that,
so we're gonna stamp it and

604
00:30:39.330 --> 00:30:42.340
seal it up, and
you don't have to worry about it.

605
00:30:42.340 --> 00:30:45.600
That's what's going on here,
is that chain of trust.

606
00:30:45.600 --> 00:30:51.570
Now, when we work with certificates, we've
got private CAs, and we've got public CAs.

607
00:30:51.570 --> 00:30:53.310
This an example of a private CA.

608
00:30:53.310 --> 00:30:57.400
I installed that root CA
on one of my own servers.

609
00:30:57.400 --> 00:31:00.990
And then I installed the intermediate
CA on another one of my servers.

610
00:31:00.990 --> 00:31:03.700
And I'm now issuing certificates
out to all my users.

611
00:31:03.700 --> 00:31:07.810
And all of my computers had been
configured to trust root CA.

612
00:31:07.810 --> 00:31:11.890
I used group policy to say, hey, here's
the root server certificate, add it to

613
00:31:11.890 --> 00:31:16.710
your trusted roots, trust any certificates
that are issued by this hierarchy.

614
00:31:16.710 --> 00:31:21.090
So it works great internally when we
use these private CA's that I set up.

615
00:31:21.090 --> 00:31:23.420
It doesn't cost me any money.

616
00:31:23.420 --> 00:31:25.960
Well I have the license for
the operating system, right.

617
00:31:25.960 --> 00:31:27.130
But I've installed it.

618
00:31:27.130 --> 00:31:30.330
I can issue all the certificates
I want all day long.

619
00:31:30.330 --> 00:31:31.240
Doesn't cost me anything.

620
00:31:31.240 --> 00:31:32.270
Right?

621
00:31:32.270 --> 00:31:33.620
And here's the problem.

622
00:31:33.620 --> 00:31:36.380
What if I issue a certificate
to my web server?

623
00:31:36.380 --> 00:31:38.785
So that my customers can
come to my website and

624
00:31:38.785 --> 00:31:41.910
setup secure socket layer,
and encrypt that traffic.

625
00:31:41.910 --> 00:31:44.430
They don't want to put their credit card
number in there until they have that

626
00:31:44.430 --> 00:31:45.880
secure connection.

627
00:31:45.880 --> 00:31:49.340
Well their computer is gonna ask my web
server, hey show me your certificate,

628
00:31:49.340 --> 00:31:52.360
send me your key so
we can start encrypting traffic.

629
00:31:52.360 --> 00:31:54.960
My server's gonna say, sure,
here's my certificate.

630
00:31:54.960 --> 00:32:00.336
Their computer looks at it and says,
root CA, who the heck is root CA?

631
00:32:00.336 --> 00:32:01.592
Don't think that's gonna work, right?

632
00:32:01.592 --> 00:32:05.552
>> Yeah, that's not one of those
lovely trusted entities out there and

633
00:32:05.552 --> 00:32:08.214
that's It's really a good
lesson on where and

634
00:32:08.214 --> 00:32:12.360
when creating your own certificate
authority is appropriate.

635
00:32:12.360 --> 00:32:14.210
If we're having a website,
we want people to attach to it,

636
00:32:14.210 --> 00:32:17.640
we're probably going to want to go with a
known entity that does this for a living.

637
00:32:17.640 --> 00:32:19.172
It's going to cost us
a little bit of money.

638
00:32:19.172 --> 00:32:20.625
Now, can we do it?

639
00:32:20.625 --> 00:32:21.585
Mike, we sure can.

640
00:32:21.585 --> 00:32:25.250
>> Absolutely, there are third parties
out there, this is what they do,

641
00:32:25.250 --> 00:32:31.835
they run certificate authorities, like
Verisign or Thought or GTE or Equifax.

642
00:32:33.270 --> 00:32:34.190
I'm trying to think.

643
00:32:34.190 --> 00:32:34.700
There's dozens.

644
00:32:34.700 --> 00:32:37.800
In fact, if we can look on my computer,
I can show you the list.

645
00:32:37.800 --> 00:32:41.300
These others, the ones beside Root,
just make that a little bit bigger here.

646
00:32:42.520 --> 00:32:47.840
All right, we can see things like, let
me sort that, Baltimore, GTE, Microsoft,

647
00:32:49.610 --> 00:32:54.520
Thought, Verisign,
these are all third-party companies.

648
00:32:54.520 --> 00:32:56.910
And I didn't have to add
these to my trusted roots,

649
00:32:56.910 --> 00:33:00.730
my operating system already
knows to trust them.

650
00:33:00.730 --> 00:33:04.780
So if I'm setting up a website that's
gonna be accessed by the public,

651
00:33:04.780 --> 00:33:07.320
most likely what I'm gonna do
is go to one of these companies,

652
00:33:07.320 --> 00:33:10.600
like Verisign, and
say I wanna buy a certificate from you.

653
00:33:10.600 --> 00:33:14.900
Have your public key infrastructure
issue my server a certificate.

654
00:33:14.900 --> 00:33:19.090
That way when that customer comes to
my website and my server presents

655
00:33:19.090 --> 00:33:23.650
the certificate to that computer that
they're using, it says Verisign, Verisign.

656
00:33:23.650 --> 00:33:25.730
Oh, I trust Verisign.

657
00:33:25.730 --> 00:33:29.330
I know they did their job and verified all
that information first before they ever

658
00:33:29.330 --> 00:33:32.770
issued the certificate, so I'm just gonna
go ahead and trust the certificate.

659
00:33:32.770 --> 00:33:35.450
They get the nice green
bar across their browser.

660
00:33:35.450 --> 00:33:37.790
They know their data is safe.

661
00:33:37.790 --> 00:33:41.160
So you got public CAs that I
can use that are much easier to

662
00:33:41.160 --> 00:33:45.130
use because they're already trusted by all
the Windows operating systems out there.

663
00:33:45.130 --> 00:33:47.390
So if I'm dealing with the public,
that's the way to go.

664
00:33:47.390 --> 00:33:49.620
There is a downside to that though.

665
00:33:49.620 --> 00:33:50.910
It costs money.

666
00:33:50.910 --> 00:33:53.670
They can be from hundreds to
thousands of dollars, and

667
00:33:53.670 --> 00:33:56.060
they have to be renewed every year or
every two years.

668
00:33:56.060 --> 00:33:58.230
So this is a recurring
cost associated with it.

669
00:33:58.230 --> 00:33:59.940
>> Good way to get on
that revocation list.

670
00:33:59.940 --> 00:34:02.290
It has expired,
you're not getting anywhere.

671
00:34:02.290 --> 00:34:02.985
>> That's right.

672
00:34:02.985 --> 00:34:03.620
[LAUGH]
>> But

673
00:34:03.620 --> 00:34:07.910
if I've got to deal with the public,
I don't want them coming to my website and

674
00:34:07.910 --> 00:34:10.750
getting a warning that says hey,
I don't know who Mike CA is.

675
00:34:10.750 --> 00:34:12.670
Are you sure you want to connect?

676
00:34:12.670 --> 00:34:14.680
They're most likely going
to close that webpage and

677
00:34:14.680 --> 00:34:16.880
go to some other site and
buy their product.

678
00:34:18.500 --> 00:34:19.430
So I might need to.

679
00:34:19.430 --> 00:34:21.770
The expense is worth it.

680
00:34:21.770 --> 00:34:26.090
Internally however, I'm not buying
certificates for every one of my users,

681
00:34:26.090 --> 00:34:27.690
it's only used in-house.

682
00:34:27.690 --> 00:34:29.860
So I don't care if the public trusts it or
not.

683
00:34:29.860 --> 00:34:31.420
So I'll set up my own
certificate authority,

684
00:34:31.420 --> 00:34:36.120
my own public fee infrastructure to issue
certificates that are used internally.

685
00:34:36.120 --> 00:34:38.050
So, in most environments,
we see that we use both.

686
00:34:38.050 --> 00:34:41.220
We've got an internal,
private certificate authority, or

687
00:34:41.220 --> 00:34:44.960
public key infrastructure, for
certificates that are used in-house.

688
00:34:44.960 --> 00:34:48.630
But then I also have a few certificates
that I've bought from a public CA,

689
00:34:48.630 --> 00:34:54.430
that use their public key infrastructure
to issue certificates to my web server,

690
00:34:54.430 --> 00:34:56.210
the front end of my mail server.

691
00:34:56.210 --> 00:35:01.290
Anything that has to be accessed by people
that aren't gonna trust my internal CA.

692
00:35:01.290 --> 00:35:05.140
So again, the key there though is,
it's all about the trust.

693
00:35:05.140 --> 00:35:08.840
So we take a look at that chain of trust
on that's been issued by a public CA,

694
00:35:08.840 --> 00:35:13.150
I've got my browser open up here, and
you see Google secures their connection.

695
00:35:13.150 --> 00:35:16.905
So if I click on this lock,
I can click on Connection.

696
00:35:16.905 --> 00:35:20.169
I can see the identity of this
website has been verified by

697
00:35:20.169 --> 00:35:22.080
Google Internet Authority G2.

698
00:35:22.080 --> 00:35:25.910
Well, that doesn't sound all that secure.

699
00:35:25.910 --> 00:35:27.650
Google is identifying themselves?

700
00:35:27.650 --> 00:35:29.067
>> They know who they are, Mike [LAUGH].

701
00:35:29.067 --> 00:35:29.988
>> They do.

702
00:35:29.988 --> 00:35:31.660
I'm supposed to just trust that.

703
00:35:31.660 --> 00:35:34.950
Well, let's see what happens if
I click Certificate Information.

704
00:35:34.950 --> 00:35:35.616
Here I can see,

705
00:35:35.616 --> 00:35:38.550
there's Google's certificate that
was issued to the web server.

706
00:35:38.550 --> 00:35:41.205
But above that,
I can see that certificate for

707
00:35:41.205 --> 00:35:44.380
Google was issued by
Google Internet Authority G2.

708
00:35:44.380 --> 00:35:47.170
That's that intermediate,
or I should say that's that

709
00:35:47.170 --> 00:35:51.350
issuing C at the bottom of that
hierarchy I was showing you earlier.

710
00:35:51.350 --> 00:35:57.040
Well, that certificate was issued by
somebody known as GeoTrust Global.

711
00:35:57.040 --> 00:36:04.410
Oh, so Google went and bought from a
third-party CA, a certificate for theirs.

712
00:36:04.410 --> 00:36:05.430
And we can chain that back up.

713
00:36:05.430 --> 00:36:10.612
If I go over here to my Settings or
this browser, and

00:36:10.612 --> 00:36:16.157
let's go to Settings and

00:36:16.157 --> 00:36:23.050
down here I'll find my HTTPS and
SSL managed certificates.

00:36:23.050 --> 00:36:27.967
And I can go into my system root,
and I can scroll down through here,

717
00:36:27.967 --> 00:36:32.801
and I can see there's GeoTrust Global,
so that's why my computer

718
00:36:32.801 --> 00:36:37.494
trusts the certificate that
Google's website is presenting.

719
00:36:37.494 --> 00:36:41.446
I'm trying to connect to Google, their
servers saying, here's my certificate,

720
00:36:41.446 --> 00:36:42.234
see I am Google.

721
00:36:42.234 --> 00:36:46.130
My computer says, well wait,
who issued you the certificate?

722
00:36:46.130 --> 00:36:51.485
Oh, it was that Google Internet Authority.

723
00:36:51.485 --> 00:36:53.320
Well, who issued them the certificate?

724
00:36:53.320 --> 00:36:55.515
Oh, GeoTrust.

725
00:36:55.515 --> 00:36:59.630
I trust GeoTrust, therefore I trust
that entire public key infrastructure,

726
00:36:59.630 --> 00:37:03.385
I'll trust your certificate, but
let's set up a secure connection.

727
00:37:03.385 --> 00:37:06.820
So that's really what PKI is all about.

728
00:37:06.820 --> 00:37:09.173
It's being able to issue certificates and

729
00:37:09.173 --> 00:37:12.321
then chain those certificates
back up to a trusted root.

730
00:37:12.321 --> 00:37:17.160
>> Very, very cool and it's basically
how we do things like secure browsing.

731
00:37:17.160 --> 00:37:19.650
That is one of the greatest
built-in functions.

732
00:37:19.650 --> 00:37:23.626
Now I can go to my bank, I can go
to Amazon, I can go to wherever and

00:37:23.626 --> 00:37:26.135
plug in that credit card information and

00:37:26.135 --> 00:37:29.702
feel fairly secure that it's
not gonna be compromised.

735
00:37:29.702 --> 00:37:31.806
There are some pretty
smart guys out there.

736
00:37:31.806 --> 00:37:35.391
But I know this PKI stuff can kinda
feel like you're drinking from a fire

737
00:37:35.391 --> 00:37:36.010
hose a lot.

00:37:36.010 --> 00:37:39.240
But the great thing about it is,
you can just watch this episode over and

739
00:37:39.240 --> 00:37:42.040

sense if it doesn't all ready.

00:37:42.040 --> 00:37:44.900
Mike, you've done a really good
job of explaining, I do believe,

741
00:37:44.900 --> 00:37:48.490
and I'm sure our audience out
there is appreciating it as well.

742
00:37:48.490 --> 00:37:52.080
Because it can feel pretty cryptic and
difficult to handle, but

743
00:37:52.080 --> 00:37:53.450
I think you laid it out very nicely.

744
00:37:53.450 --> 00:37:57.244
>> Good, good, it's complex, remember for
this exam just understand the difference

745
00:37:57.244 --> 00:38:01.104
between a public certificate of authority
and private, where I would see those used.

746
00:38:01.104 --> 00:38:04.638
Remember about that certificate
reification list, that I have to be able

747
00:38:04.638 --> 00:38:08.500
to verify that a certificate's being

748
00:38:08.500 --> 00:38:10.300
And remember that concept of trust.

749
00:38:10.300 --> 00:38:11.290
>> That's right.

750
00:38:11.290 --> 00:38:13.914
Mike is there anything else we need

751
00:38:13.914 --> 00:38:14.760
>> I think that's it.

752
00:38:14.760 --> 00:38:15.420
>> All right.

753
00:38:15.420 --> 00:38:16.390
Well, hopefully you enjoyed it.

754
00:38:16.390 --> 00:38:17.930
We had a great time making it for you.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain the details of permissions. They describe the different types of permissions like File Permissions and Share Permissions, as well as what permissions are available for the NTFS and FAT file systems. They also cover the topics of inheritance, ownership, delegation, and best practices when setting permissions.

the exam, but as you get into IT this

I go back over here and

581
00:30:18.550 --> 00:30:19.849

>> We now know what to do.

583

Now, Mike, you got any other cool tricks
in your bag of tricks over there for
