585
00:30:26.900 --> 00:30:32.930
>> I think the only thing we forgot or
didn't get to was taking ownership.

586
00:30:32.930 --> 00:30:37.191
And rather than, and it's not really
anything exciting to see, but

587
00:30:37.191 --> 00:30:41.161
just understand that the owner of
an object is a special person,

588
00:30:41.161 --> 00:30:43.090
you're special, all right?

589
00:30:43.090 --> 00:30:46.817
If you create something, you are
considered the owner of that object, so

590
00:30:46.817 --> 00:30:50.380
those files that I created, right,
I'm the owner of those objects.

591
00:30:51.430 --> 00:30:54.820
Which means I have full
control because I created it.

592
00:30:54.820 --> 00:30:56.050
I'm the creator owner.

593
00:30:56.050 --> 00:30:59.350
In fact we can look, I'll show you,
if we take a look here.

594
00:30:59.350 --> 00:31:07.770
Let me go over to one of these guys, pull
up those Properties and go to Security.

595
00:31:07.770 --> 00:31:11.811
Oh, and I'm logged on as an administrator
so we're not really gonna see it there,

596
00:31:11.811 --> 00:31:13.383
but maybe if I go into Advanced.

597
00:31:13.383 --> 00:31:16.030
You're not gonna see it there either.

598
00:31:16.030 --> 00:31:19.020
But the creator owner gets full control,
and

599
00:31:19.020 --> 00:31:21.400
sometimes this can cause
a problem in an environment.

600
00:31:21.400 --> 00:31:26.540
Let's say that I assign Daniel the job
of creating a master phone list for

601
00:31:26.540 --> 00:31:27.520
the company.

602
00:31:27.520 --> 00:31:31.240
So Daniel does his job, he gets out his
Excel spreadsheet or whatever he decides

603
00:31:31.240 --> 00:31:35.420
to use, and creates this master phone
list, and puts it up on the network share.

604
00:31:36.450 --> 00:31:39.900
Well now he's the creator
owner of that file.

605
00:31:39.900 --> 00:31:41.490
Means he has full control.

606
00:31:41.490 --> 00:31:45.760
Full control can change permissions on it,
and delete the object.

607
00:31:45.760 --> 00:31:49.470
And so if Daniel got mad, and
said you know what, that Mike guy,

608
00:31:49.470 --> 00:31:51.140
he just drives me crazy.

609
00:31:51.140 --> 00:31:53.540
I'm gonna take away his
permissions on this phone list.

610
00:31:53.540 --> 00:31:55.820
Now all of a sudden I can't
get access to that phone list,

611
00:31:55.820 --> 00:31:59.470
all because Daniel got mad cuz I
parked in his parking spot, right?

612
00:31:59.470 --> 00:32:01.610
And he really gets upset about that.

613
00:32:01.610 --> 00:32:04.260
So the creator can change
those permissions.

614
00:32:04.260 --> 00:32:05.810
And it shouldn't be up to Daniel, right?

615
00:32:05.810 --> 00:32:09.042
Daniel's not the boss, Daniel was just
tasked with that responsibility of

616
00:32:09.042 --> 00:32:11.400
creating that document in the first place.

617
00:32:11.400 --> 00:32:15.060
So we can change who
the owner of the document is.

618
00:32:15.060 --> 00:32:19.960
As an administrator with full control,
I can go in and change the owner.

619
00:32:19.960 --> 00:32:21.950
Usually what we'll do,

620
00:32:21.950 --> 00:32:25.740
is we assign ownership to
the administrators group, right?

621
00:32:25.740 --> 00:32:27.890
That way it's not tied to one individual.

622
00:32:27.890 --> 00:32:30.240
What if Daniel leaves the company?

623
00:32:30.240 --> 00:32:32.650
Who is the owner of that document now?

624
00:32:32.650 --> 00:32:36.081
It just becomes a little bit troublesome
when working with those documents.

625
00:32:36.081 --> 00:32:39.833
So that's something you can do in NTFS.

626
00:32:39.833 --> 00:32:42.950
Just understand that
the creator of a document or

627
00:32:42.950 --> 00:32:46.835
a folder is considered the owner and
they have full control.

628
00:32:46.835 --> 00:32:49.314
So sometimes we need to take
that away from them and

629
00:32:49.314 --> 00:32:52.430
assign that ownership to
the administrators group.

630
00:32:52.430 --> 00:32:56.040
>> That's right, super handy with those
orphaned files that somebody's gone,

631
00:32:56.040 --> 00:32:59.480
they no longer exist, or
it's just kind of hanging out there.

632
00:32:59.480 --> 00:33:02.570
And no one has the ability to do anything
with it because the owner does not

633
00:33:02.570 --> 00:33:03.490
exist anymore [LAUGH].

634
00:33:03.490 --> 00:33:06.530
So it's very helpful for
us to be able to take that ownership and

635
00:33:06.530 --> 00:33:08.618
reclaim our power over it.

636
00:33:08.618 --> 00:33:11.118
Mike, [LAUGH]-
>> I was just thinking, that's a great,

637
00:33:11.118 --> 00:33:12.790
you just made me think of something else.

638
00:33:12.790 --> 00:33:17.110
What about that user that has documents
stored up in folder redirection, right,

639
00:33:17.110 --> 00:33:17.800
and they've left.

640
00:33:18.890 --> 00:33:21.760
They've important documents in
there that only they had access to.

641
00:33:23.030 --> 00:33:23.710
How do I get in there?

642
00:33:23.710 --> 00:33:25.220
How do I get access to those documents?

643
00:33:25.220 --> 00:33:27.910
Well as an admin I can take
ownership of those documents and

644
00:33:27.910 --> 00:33:30.300
reassign the permissions so
everybody can get access to those.

645
00:33:30.300 --> 00:33:31.150
So great point Daniel.

646
00:33:31.150 --> 00:33:32.340
>> Yeah very good stuff.

647
00:33:32.340 --> 00:33:35.680
All right, Mike, looks like we've come
to the end of another excellent episode.

648
00:33:35.680 --> 00:33:37.423
Thank you so much for
those demonstrations.

649

Explaining this permissions business can
be a bit of a bear but you can watch this

650
00:33:41.376 --> 00:33:44.578
episode over and over again until
it starts to make sense to you.

651
00:33:44.578 --> 00:33:46.631
And one day, trust us, it will.

652
00:33:46.631 --> 00:33:50.852
And then you'll be on the fast track
to being a sys admin, just like us.

653

[LAUGH] All right, that being said,
we're gonna sign off for ITProTV.

654
00:33:54.345 --> 00:33:56.205
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel describe the best practices when it comes to setting up password and audit policies. They start off by showing you where to set the password policy on both a local Windows desktop OS as well as in a Active Directory domain environment; explaining each of the settings available. Then they move into auditing where they show you how to enable auditing and the different types of auditing available in a Windows environment.
episodes.title: Password and Audit Policies

89
00:04:22.940 --> 00:04:23.830
>> Right.

90

00:04:26.700 --> 00:04:30.250

00:04:30.250 --> 00:04:32.080

Why do I care if my user basically

It seems like it's going against security.

Our users who can not figure out

101
00:04:56.980 --> 00:05:00.520
What they will do if Daniel's
favorite password is blue.

00:05:00.520 --> 00:05:04.510
So when it comes time to change his
password, guess what he's gonna do?

103
00:05:04.510 --> 00:05:07.570

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike walk you through the basics of encryption. Here they show you some of the different encryption types as well as detail the concept of public/private keys. They then move into Windows' Encrypting File System(EFS) to encrypt files on a hard drive, mail encryption and signing files to verify their integrity.

If Bob receives this email,
what he's gonna do is he's going to,

566
00:30:39.350 --> 00:30:42.240
he thinks it's from Alice but
he wants to verify that.

567
00:30:42.240 --> 00:30:48.260
Well, Bob is gonna get Alice's certificate
which contains her public key.

568
00:30:48.260 --> 00:30:50.760
Remember the way asymmetric works.

569
00:30:50.760 --> 00:30:52.680
If I encrypt it with one key,

570
00:30:52.680 --> 00:30:56.470
the only key that can decrypt it
is the other half of the key pair.

571
00:30:56.470 --> 00:30:59.940
If she encrypted this
with her private key,

572
00:30:59.940 --> 00:31:04.230
then the only key that can decrypt it,
is Alice's public key.

573
00:31:04.230 --> 00:31:08.640
So if Bob can successfully
use Alice's public key

574
00:31:08.640 --> 00:31:13.860
to decrypt that hash value,
and get that hash value out,,

575
00:31:13.860 --> 00:31:18.260
then it had to be encrypted with
Alice's private key in the first place.

576
00:31:18.260 --> 00:31:21.980
And the only person that has
Alice's private key is Alice.

577
00:31:21.980 --> 00:31:24.470
Which means that this email
had to come from Alice.

578
00:31:24.470 --> 00:31:27.210
All right, that's that non-repudiation.

579
00:31:27.210 --> 00:31:32.690
Now Bob has this hash value, and what
he's going to do is take the email and

580
00:31:32.690 --> 00:31:36.360
run it through the same algorithm and
generate his own hash value.

581
00:31:36.360 --> 00:31:40.850
And then he is going to compare the one
that Alice sent with the email and

582
00:31:40.850 --> 00:31:42.600
the one that he just generated.

583
00:31:42.600 --> 00:31:47.870
If those match exactly, then he now knows
that the email has not been modified.

584
00:31:47.870 --> 00:31:51.220
It's exactly the same
as when Alice sent it.

585
00:31:51.220 --> 00:31:55.920
If these two didn't match, then something
happened to that email during transit.

586
00:31:55.920 --> 00:31:56.730
Could be malicious.

587
00:31:56.730 --> 00:31:59.680
Could be just normal data corruption or
something like that.

588
00:31:59.680 --> 00:32:00.742
But either way.

589
00:32:00.742 --> 00:32:01.745
>> It.
>> Yeah.

590
00:32:01.745 --> 00:32:03.940
[LAUGH]
>> He'll break an anvil, that boy.

591
00:32:03.940 --> 00:32:05.579
[LAUGH]
>> So

592
00:32:05.579 --> 00:32:08.643
either way I know something has changed.

593
00:32:08.643 --> 00:32:12.195
It's just not what Alice intended for
me to receive, and I can say hey Alice,

594
00:32:12.195 --> 00:32:14.200
that email didn't come through.

595
00:32:14.200 --> 00:32:16.240
Send it to me again, all right?

596
00:32:16.240 --> 00:32:18.790
So email signatures give us two things.

597
00:32:18.790 --> 00:32:22.620
They give us that non-repudiation,
I was able to validate or

598
00:32:22.620 --> 00:32:28.210
verify the identity of the sender, it did
come from Alice, as well as integrity,

599
00:32:28.210 --> 00:32:33.490
I was able to verify that that document
had not been modified during transit.

600
00:32:33.490 --> 00:32:38.560
So just another way we see a combination
of these encryptions being used.

601
00:32:38.560 --> 00:32:42.700
In this case, we're using hashing and
asymmetric encryption.

602
00:32:42.700 --> 00:32:43.660
>> Awesome stuff.

603
00:32:43.660 --> 00:32:46.850
Obviously, encryption is a very handy,
dandy thing to have sticking around,

604
00:32:46.850 --> 00:32:49.850
cuz we want to be able to do
those things like nonrepudiation.

605
00:32:49.850 --> 00:32:51.780
We wanna verify that integrity.

606
00:32:51.780 --> 00:32:54.750
And sometimes we just don't want people
being able to see or look at data,

607
00:32:54.750 --> 00:32:57.090
because it's sensitive information.

608
00:32:57.090 --> 00:32:59.090
So encryption is definitely here to stay,
so

609
00:32:59.090 --> 00:33:01.900
it does help us to
understand how they work.

610
00:33:01.900 --> 00:33:04.390
Mike, you've done a great job so
far of showing us.

611
00:33:04.390 --> 00:33:06.574
I'm seeing the light, it's making it easy,

612
00:33:06.574 --> 00:33:08.656
I didn't need a math
degree to do it either.

613
00:33:08.656 --> 00:33:09.283
>> I told you.

614
00:33:09.283 --> 00:33:10.537
>> That's right.
>> No calculators here.

615
00:33:10.537 --> 00:33:11.582
>> It's been good so far.

616
00:33:11.582 --> 00:33:13.272
Now I know we got plenty
more to go through, so

617
00:33:13.272 --> 00:33:16.040
it looks like we're gonna have to
do a part two on this episode.

618
00:33:16.040 --> 00:33:18.387
But there's a lot more
fun to come up ahead.

619
00:33:18.387 --> 00:33:19.513
Hopefully, we'll see you there.

620
00:33:19.513 --> 00:33:21.290
Thanks for those demonstrations, Mike.

621
00:33:21.290 --> 00:33:22.900
>> You're welcome.
>> We're gonna go ahead and sign off for

622
00:33:22.900 --> 00:33:23.830
this episode, though.

623
00:33:23.830 --> 00:33:26.680
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

624
00:33:26.680 --> 00:33:27.330
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

00:33:27.330 --> 00:33:28.947
>> And we'll see you next time.

Like Daniel said in another

34

So, when you format a volume using the
NTFS file system, that gives you access to

35

36

NEFS is really simple to do, in fact,

45

46

Next set I have got my advanced button,
in here I can either compress or

47

48
00:02:19.810 --> 00:02:24.350
Now a little bit of a goof in my

proper etiquette says radio buttons

MasterCard, or Discover.

00:02:30.160 --> 00:02:33.040
Checkmarks when you can

52

This is not the case here though.

53

You can either encrypt a file or

54

Both are properties of NTFS and

00:02:41.130 --> 00:02:45.990
So, if you, it'll let you do it sort of or

56
00:02:45.990 --> 00:02:47.780
Right?
If you encrypt a file, like I'm going to.

00:02:47.780 --> 00:02:48.360
Well, I'll show you.
Sure.

58
00:02:48.360 --> 00:02:50.420
Yeah, heck,
let's not talk about it let's do it.

59
00:02:50.420 --> 00:02:52.250
I'm gonna encrypt contents
to secure data and

00:02:52.250 --> 00:02:55.970
I'm gonna click OK and I'll click OK

ask me if I wanna do the folder that

Best Practice is always encrypt

That way, the folder, remember,

Anybody can still get into that folder but

00:03:17.430 --> 00:03:21.300
down to the files inside there and
remember it'll use your keys so

00:03:21.300 --> 00:03:24.950
if Daniel puts a file in that

00:03:24.950 --> 00:03:26.680
It's encrypted to one of Daniel's keys,

if I put a file in there it

00:03:29.500 --> 00:03:32.770
Daniel couldn't get it but this demo

Now Mike if you encrypt a folder that you

00:03:36.500 --> 00:03:39.580

>> Mm.
Nope it will, it'll go back and

Right click properties,

That's the indication

So, now only I can double

00:04:17.730 --> 00:04:20.570
I don't have to do anything,

00:04:20.570 --> 00:04:24.950
My key is stored in my user profile and

00:04:24.950 --> 00:04:28.100

92
00:04:28.100 --> 00:04:31.570
Remember we talked about the whole
public key and private key and

00:04:31.570 --> 00:04:33.210
the file encryption key.

So, we've got my private key,

the data decryption field, grabbed

decrypted the document,

Notepad opens up, and here we go and

I can type data in here I

I don't have to do anything right?

00:04:51.810 --> 00:04:55.590

101
00:04:55.590 --> 00:04:59.330
because it hands it back to the file

102
00:04:59.330 --> 00:05:01.430
The filesystem then turns it around and
encrypts it and

103
00:05:01.430 --> 00:05:03.120
puts it back on the hard drive.

104
00:05:03.120 --> 00:05:06.380
All right, now if I just, I don't know

00:05:20.600 --> 00:05:24.930
If you try to encrypt a compressed file,

00:05:24.930 --> 00:05:27.830

00:05:27.830 --> 00:05:29.910
you won't be able to compress

112
00:05:29.910 --> 00:05:34.635
Cuz it can't decrypt it first and
then compress it so it wouldn't let you.

113
00:05:34.635 --> 00:05:37.095
All right, and we also talked about and

00:05:37.095 --> 00:05:41.505
I don't actually remove the encryption.

00:05:41.505 --> 00:05:44.647
If I go back in here and I click details,
this is where I can share.

116
00:05:44.647 --> 00:05:47.727
Remember we talked about one of the cool
things about EFS is I can share

117
00:05:47.727 --> 00:05:49.357
the file with other users.

118
00:05:49.357 --> 00:05:51.137
All we have to do is click add and

119
00:05:51.137 --> 00:05:55.297
if there were other users that had

00:05:55.297 --> 00:05:59.160
I could browse through active directory

00:05:59.160 --> 00:06:03.110
add them here, and then they would be

122
00:06:03.110 --> 00:06:08.430
So, if we need to share encrypted files,
very easy to do because we published those

123
00:06:08.430 --> 00:06:11.640
certificates and active directory and
then remember, the public key is public.

124
00:06:11.640 --> 00:06:13.240
Anybody could have it, so.

125
00:06:13.240 --> 00:06:15.650
We make them readily available,
very easy to do.

126
00:06:15.650 --> 00:06:20.160
All right so that's our EFS and again,

127
00:06:20.160 --> 00:06:25.800
with EFS, you know, we're using, we're
encrypting a single file which is nice.

128
00:06:25.800 --> 00:06:28.930
If I need to protect that file,
we know we've got NTFS permissions,

129
00:06:28.930 --> 00:06:34.240
we can control who can or can't access
that but remember with NTFS permissions

130
00:06:34.240 --> 00:06:39.740
it's based on users SID, security
identifier and the SID of a group.

131
00:06:39.740 --> 00:06:42.750
So, let's say I don't want
Daniel to get access to it.

132
00:06:42.750 --> 00:06:47.100
Well, NTFS doesn't have Daniel
listed there as an allow,

133
00:06:47.100 --> 00:06:50.660
there's no ACE,
access control entry for Daniel but

134
00:06:50.660 --> 00:06:55.350
there is an access control entry for
say a group called hosts.

135
00:06:55.350 --> 00:06:57.850
Well if Daniel ever gets
added to that group,

136
00:06:57.850 --> 00:07:00.530
all of a sudden he's gonna get
access to the file, all right.

137
00:07:00.530 --> 00:07:05.300
So, then DFS permissions, there's
a chance it goes on an implicit deny,

138
00:07:05.300 --> 00:07:09.390
which means at some point somebody
else could give Daniel access.

139
00:07:09.390 --> 00:07:11.480
With encryption that is
not going to happen.

140
00:07:11.480 --> 00:07:15.980
I don't care what groups Daniel belongs
to he is not getting access to that file

141
00:07:15.980 --> 00:07:19.150
unless I choose to share that
encrypted file with him.

142
00:07:19.150 --> 00:07:23.810
So, that is why we have this right, that
is why it is another layer of security as

143
00:07:23.810 --> 00:07:29.000
a way to add on top of the security
we already get through NTFS but

144
00:07:29.000 --> 00:07:33.970
it is protecting an individual file and
if we've got lots of files.

145
00:07:33.970 --> 00:07:37.649
I'm trying to think of a good
way to say it is good for

146
00:07:37.649 --> 00:07:42.616
protecting individual files but
if somebody steals my hard drive and

147
00:07:42.616 --> 00:07:46.314
they try to slave that
drive into another machine.

148
00:07:46.314 --> 00:07:50.332
Anything that's not encrypted they're
going to be able to gain access to,

149
00:07:50.332 --> 00:07:54.474
if it's encrypted they shouldn't be able
to but sometimes we want to be able to

150
00:07:54.474 --> 00:07:58.806
protect the entire drive, especially on
mobile devices where they can get lost or

151
00:07:58.806 --> 00:08:01.305
stolen and
that's where BitLocker comes in.

152
00:08:01.305 --> 00:08:03.466
BitLocker is a full drive encryption.

153
00:08:03.466 --> 00:08:06.450
It encrypts everything on the drive.

154
00:08:06.450 --> 00:08:10.760
And that way if somebody tries to
steal it and put it in another machine

155
00:08:10.760 --> 00:08:14.360
like they walk into your server closet and
they grab a couple of those hard drives.

156
00:08:14.360 --> 00:08:19.220
They just pop them out of those removable
cages and try to take them home or if they

157
00:08:19.220 --> 00:08:22.350
can't break into your laptop, they can't
get your password, so they disassemble it.

158
00:08:22.350 --> 00:08:25.960
They take the hard drive out and
they try to slave into another machine.

159
00:08:25.960 --> 00:08:28.630
BitLocker's gonna protect us
against things like that.

160
00:08:28.630 --> 00:08:29.540

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike help you better understand what malware is, how you get it, and how to protect against it. Here they cover malware attacks like viruses and worms, spyware, and buffer overflows. episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel describe the benefits and attributes of a dedicated firewall solution and Network Access Protection (NAP). Here they discuss the different types of dedicated firewalls, like Unified Threat Management(UTM) system, Secure Content Managment(SCM) systems, and what the difference is between stateful and stateless firewalls. Finally they walk you through Microsoft's NAP system and even show you NAP in action.

00:28:48.230 --> 00:28:52.390
We can definitely use
more than one solution.

561
00:28:52.390 --> 00:28:53.209
All right, let's take a peek here.

562
00:28:53.209 --> 00:28:57.001
So again on my machine,
he's currently compliant, and

563
00:28:57.001 --> 00:28:59.849
all I'm going to do is
open up my firewall.

564
00:29:03.809 --> 00:29:06.309
And I'm gonna turn it off.

565
00:29:06.309 --> 00:29:09.889
So we'll just say turn off firewall and
click OK.

566
00:29:09.889 --> 00:29:14.489
And notice almost immediately, I get a
little pop-up down here in my system tray.

567
00:29:14.489 --> 00:29:16.909
If I click on that, oops,
I just turned it back on, sorry.

568
00:29:16.909 --> 00:29:18.136
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let me turn that back off,

569
00:29:18.136 --> 00:29:18.787
let's turn it off.

570
00:29:18.787 --> 00:29:20.367
>> [CROSSTALK] compliance for that.

571
00:29:20.367 --> 00:29:21.606
[LAUGH]
>> And click OK.

572
00:29:21.606 --> 00:29:22.386
>> Rule follower.

573
00:29:22.386 --> 00:29:23.120
>> And there we go.

574
00:29:23.120 --> 00:29:24.380
This is the one we one we want.

575
00:29:24.380 --> 00:29:27.830
Here's the message, this is what
the users are going to get on their end.

576
00:29:27.830 --> 00:29:31.040
Computer does not meet security standards
defined by your network administrator,

577
00:29:31.040 --> 00:29:33.220
you might have limited access.

578
00:29:33.220 --> 00:29:36.180
And it even tells me,
it should down here, let's see.

579
00:29:38.660 --> 00:29:42.425
An administrator must enable a firewall
program that is compatible with

580
00:29:42.425 --> 00:29:44.039
the Windows Security Center.

581
00:29:44.039 --> 00:29:45.900
All right, and I think that's fantastic.

582
00:29:45.900 --> 00:29:48.480
Rather than the user
just lost connectivity.

583
00:29:48.480 --> 00:29:51.530
I can't connect to any resources,
what the heck is going on?

584
00:29:51.530 --> 00:29:54.360
Right, and then they call the help
desk and blah, blah, blah.

585
00:29:54.360 --> 00:29:56.306
Hey, this is telling them,
you need a firewall.

586
00:29:56.306 --> 00:30:00.491
So if your user's at home, and they
can't figure out why they can't connect,

587
00:30:00.491 --> 00:30:01.980
this is gonna tell them.

588
00:30:01.980 --> 00:30:03.270
And notice it was almost immediate.

589
00:30:03.270 --> 00:30:05.970
And if I go back over
here to my IP config now,

590
00:30:09.200 --> 00:30:12.380
we're gonna say quarantine
state restricted.

591
00:30:12.380 --> 00:30:16.470
And notice that I've got an IP address,
but my subnet mask is all ones.

592
00:30:16.470 --> 00:30:19.300
So I want a network of one
basically all by myself.

593
00:30:19.300 --> 00:30:23.380
Now I didn't setup a,
a remediation network for this demo, but

594
00:30:23.380 --> 00:30:24.220
you can see I'm restricted.

595
00:30:24.220 --> 00:30:26.150
I'm not gonna get access to anything.

596
00:30:26.150 --> 00:30:31.469
And you can see my DNS suffix
is now restricted.lab.itpro.tv.

597
00:30:31.469 --> 00:30:35.943
These are things that I can use to control
what they have access to when they

598
00:30:35.943 --> 00:30:37.829
are quarantined, all right?

599
00:30:37.829 --> 00:30:41.189
And now if I just go back over here and
turn my firewall back on.

600
00:30:45.269 --> 00:30:47.749
All right, we're good to go there.

601
00:30:47.749 --> 00:30:49.208
And now I do a little ipconfig.

602
00:30:49.208 --> 00:30:54.748
Oh, let's see, I might have to release and
renew to get that guy to pop back out.

603
00:30:54.748 --> 00:30:58.341
It'll happen automatically,
but if I do this,

604
00:30:58.341 --> 00:31:01.768
it will speed the process
up just a little bit.

605
00:31:05.648 --> 00:31:06.715
We'll let that renew.

606
00:31:06.715 --> 00:31:09.615
And now I should get an IP address
with a valid subnet mask and

607
00:31:09.615 --> 00:31:11.595
I should no longer be restricted.

608
00:31:12.805 --> 00:31:13.685
And there we go.

609
00:31:13.685 --> 00:31:18.003
I'm back to lab.itpro.tv instead
of restricted.lab.itpro.tv.

610
00:31:18.003 --> 00:31:21.377
>> You know what I like about this Mike is
that even though it gives them that nice

611
00:31:21.377 --> 00:31:24.751
warning message, this is exactly why
you're being put into remediation,

612
00:31:24.751 --> 00:31:27.089
because you're not following
a proper procedure.

613
00:31:27.089 --> 00:31:29.589
And even though that's gonna
generate a help desk call.

614
00:31:29.589 --> 00:31:31.601
I mean it'd be nice if there
were no help desk calls that go,

615
00:31:31.601 --> 00:31:33.029
oh well I've just done something wrong.

616
00:31:33.029 --> 00:31:36.420
I'll have to fix this but
that's probably not gonna happen.

617
00:31:36.420 --> 00:31:37.600
They're gonna call a help desk and

618
00:31:37.600 --> 00:31:41.940
say, I'm getting this error message saying
that I'm out of compliance in some way.

619
00:31:41.940 --> 00:31:44.810
It says something about
a firewall being turned off.

620
00:31:44.810 --> 00:31:47.650
The help desk now knows exactly
what the problem is, right?

621
00:31:47.650 --> 00:31:51.560
It points them right to the issue,
whereas if it didn't do that,

622
00:31:51.560 --> 00:31:55.020
they would call the help desk anyway and
say I don't know what's going on.

623
00:31:55.020 --> 00:31:56.650
There's something wrong with my computer.

624
00:31:56.650 --> 00:31:59.220
And now we've gotta walk through
troubleshooting stuff trying to figure out

625
00:31:59.220 --> 00:32:01.450
why they're not getting access and
then go, oh, lo and

626
00:32:01.450 --> 00:32:05.810
behold, you're not meeting the criteria
that we've set up for network access.

627
00:32:05.810 --> 00:32:06.830
You've gotta fix that.

628
00:32:06.830 --> 00:32:07.353
>> Exactly.
So

629
00:32:07.353 --> 00:32:10.803
it saves you a lot of time doing
that troubleshooting process.

630
00:32:10.803 --> 00:32:15.132
And again, that auto remediation can be
set up to where, like the firewall for

631
00:32:15.132 --> 00:32:19.066
example, like I said, I intentionally
unchecked auto remediation so

632
00:32:19.066 --> 00:32:22.310
that I could show you
a restricted machine.

633
00:32:22.310 --> 00:32:25.610
If I didn't do that, it would have
just turned the firewall back on and

634
00:32:25.610 --> 00:32:27.590
the user might not have ever even noticed.

635
00:32:27.590 --> 00:32:29.700
And I would have said all right,
I'm going to turn that on for you, and

636
00:32:29.700 --> 00:32:31.990
now you can have access to
the rest of the network.

637
00:32:31.990 --> 00:32:36.000
If I have WSUS set up for
my updates, and things like that,

638
00:32:36.000 --> 00:32:37.370
I can automate that as well, right?

639
00:32:37.370 --> 00:32:40.510
So you get kicked over to
the remediation portion,

640
00:32:40.510 --> 00:32:43.860
it automatically downloads updates for
our corporate anti-virus software and for

641
00:32:43.860 --> 00:32:46.190
Windows updates, and
then kicks them back out.

642
00:32:46.190 --> 00:32:49.860
So a lot of this can be
automated to fix that.

643
00:32:49.860 --> 00:32:51.640
It's a really handy thing.

644
00:32:51.640 --> 00:32:53.990
Like I said, it really helps us protect.

645
00:32:53.990 --> 00:32:57.410
In today's world we got strange
computers connecting to our network, and

646
00:32:57.410 --> 00:32:59.040
we've gotta make sure
we're keeping that safe.

647
00:32:59.040 --> 00:33:01.670
>> That's right, very transient
environment sending more, so

648
00:33:01.670 --> 00:33:04.260
we gotta take all
the necessary precautions and

649
00:33:04.260 --> 00:33:07.710
actions that we can, like Mike said,
to keep that network safe.

650
00:33:07.710 --> 00:33:08.550
Thanks so much for that, Mike,

651
00:33:08.550 --> 00:33:11.440
is there anything else that we need
to go over before we call it a day?

652
00:33:11.440 --> 00:33:12.400
>> I think we're good to go.

653
00:33:12.400 --> 00:33:13.110
>> All right.

654
00:33:13.110 --> 00:33:15.380
Well everyone, we're gonna go ahead and
call it a day, then.

655
00:33:15.380 --> 00:33:18.167
Thanks for watching the show,
we're signing off for ITProTV,

656
00:33:18.167 --> 00:33:19.879
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

657
00:33:19.879 --> 00:33:20.659
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

658
00:33:20.659 --> 00:33:22.878
>> And we'll see you next time.

659
00:33:22.878 --> 00:33:28.690

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain the purpose of network isolation and how network isolation is practically implemented. They start with one of the most common forms of isolation, which is using Virtual Local Area Networks or VLANs and routing. Then they cover more specifically isolated devices like VPN connected devices, honeypots, and perimeter networks, aka a DMZ.
episodes.title: Network Isolation
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.147 --> 00:00:10.147
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.917 --> 00:00:16.890
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.890 --> 00:00:19.600
I'm your host Daniel Lowry,
joining me in the studio today, well,

4
00:00:19.600 --> 00:00:21.107
it's none other than Mike Roderick.

5
00:00:21.107 --> 00:00:22.663
Welcome to the show, Mike,
how are you doing today?

6
00:00:22.663 --> 00:00:24.103
>> I'm doing great, Daniel.

7
00:00:24.103 --> 00:00:26.838
We've got more of our MTA
content coming your way, and

8
00:00:26.838 --> 00:00:28.398
you know what that does for me?

9
00:00:28.398 --> 00:00:31.560
It gets me all excited and
bubbly cuz we get to talk about security.

10
00:00:31.560 --> 00:00:36.360
This one, we're talking about network
isolation which is one of those things.

11
00:00:36.360 --> 00:00:38.050
Wait, I don't want my
network to be isolated.

12
00:00:38.050 --> 00:00:39.252
I wanna connect to other networks.

13
00:00:39.252 --> 00:00:42.530
I wanna get access to resources
all over the place, and we do, but

14
00:00:42.530 --> 00:00:43.812
we wanna protect our network.

15
00:00:43.812 --> 00:00:45.230
We've gotta keep it safe.

16
00:00:45.230 --> 00:00:48.860
And when we talk about network isolation,
we're really kinda talking about making

17
00:00:48.860 --> 00:00:52.120
sure that only the right people can get
onto our network, isolating it from all of

18
00:00:52.120 --> 00:00:55.740
the other baddies out there, things
that shouldn't exist on our network.

19
00:00:55.740 --> 00:00:57.500
>> That's right.
It just makes sense

20
00:00:57.500 --> 00:00:59.980
that even though you
have one large network,

21
00:00:59.980 --> 00:01:04.970
there's no reason that the HR department
dives into the research department.

22
00:01:04.970 --> 00:01:08.260
What's the point of crossing
that traffic together?

23
00:01:08.260 --> 00:01:11.630
It doesn't make any sense, so
sometimes we wanna isolate that.

24
00:01:11.630 --> 00:01:15.520
Obviously, for security reasons we also
wanna isolate certain things like,

25
00:01:15.520 --> 00:01:17.815
I don't know, maybe our servers and
the data that's on them.

26
00:01:17.815 --> 00:01:19.410
>> [LAUGH]
>> That might be a good idea to

27
00:01:19.410 --> 00:01:21.280
isolate that network as well.

28
00:01:21.280 --> 00:01:25.010
So we're gonna show you a few tricks and
tips to be able to do that, some common

29
00:01:25.010 --> 00:01:28.528
ways in which we employ network
isolation for those specific purposes.

30
00:01:28.528 --> 00:01:31.460
And Mike, you got a lot of cool
stuff lined up for us today.

31
00:01:31.460 --> 00:01:33.490
So where do we begin, good Sir?

32
00:01:33.490 --> 00:01:35.790
>> I think we'll start with virtual LANs.

33
00:01:35.790 --> 00:01:38.870
And before we can talk about virtual LANs,
we need to do a little refresher and

34
00:01:38.870 --> 00:01:40.980
just make sure we're
familiar with the LAN.

35
00:01:40.980 --> 00:01:46.710
A LAN is a local area network,
typically isolated to a building or

36
00:01:46.710 --> 00:01:49.930
even a floor of a multi-storey building,
or

37
00:01:49.930 --> 00:01:53.370
it could be a group of buildings,
but a local area network.

38
00:01:53.370 --> 00:01:56.950
It usually implies physically
things that are tied together,

39
00:01:56.950 --> 00:01:59.520
all connected to the same little network.

40
00:02:00.830 --> 00:02:04.840
We have a soho, for example,
we might have a single LAN environment.

41
00:02:04.840 --> 00:02:06.690
We've only got four or five computers.

42
00:02:06.690 --> 00:02:10.220
As we move up in size to our larger and

43
00:02:10.220 --> 00:02:15.350
larger networks, that LAN starts
growing and growing and growing.

44
00:02:15.350 --> 00:02:19.730
And remember how Ethernet works,
it's a contention-based protocol.

45
00:02:19.730 --> 00:02:22.490
In other words, you gotta fight for
time on the network.

46
00:02:22.490 --> 00:02:25.000
So if I have ten nodes on
a little local area network,

47
00:02:25.000 --> 00:02:27.360
a little subnet,
then they're all competing for time.

48
00:02:27.360 --> 00:02:30.859
But with only ten other people,
imagine being in a room with ten people.

49
00:02:30.859 --> 00:02:32.426
It's pretty easy to talk, right?

50
00:02:32.426 --> 00:02:36.320
If you've got something to say, you just
speak up and everybody hears you talking.

51
00:02:36.320 --> 00:02:39.150
They all hush and you continue to speak.

52
00:02:39.150 --> 00:02:44.575
But now increase the number of people
in that room to 20, 50, a hundred,

53
00:02:44.575 --> 00:02:49.585
200, now how easy is it to get
everybody's attention and say hey,

54
00:02:49.585 --> 00:02:52.570
I've got something to say, and
try to speak so everybody can hear you.

55
00:02:52.570 --> 00:02:56.260
Or at least the person you're trying
to talk can hear you, cuz you got 100,

56
00:02:56.260 --> 00:02:58.730
50 different conversations going on.

57
00:02:58.730 --> 00:03:00.500
It becomes very difficult.

58
00:03:00.500 --> 00:03:02.534
It's the same thing that's
happening with our computers.

59
00:03:02.534 --> 00:03:06.259
If I've got five or ten nodes on there,
not that big of a deal.

60
00:03:06.259 --> 00:03:10.297
If I get up to a hundred, 200 nodes,
there's a lot of nodes fighting for

61
00:03:10.297 --> 00:03:14.589
time on the network that they need to
speak, they need to connect to a resource,

62
00:03:14.589 --> 00:03:16.150
and think about broadcast.

63
00:03:16.150 --> 00:03:18.715
There's a lot of broadcast
traffic that goes on.

64
00:03:18.715 --> 00:03:21.894
If you've ever run a packet capture
utility on your home network,

65
00:03:21.894 --> 00:03:23.610
where you're not doing anything.

66
00:03:23.610 --> 00:03:25.120
You're not connected to the Internet.

67
00:03:25.120 --> 00:03:27.250
You're just sitting there
watching Wireshark.

68
00:03:27.250 --> 00:03:30.140
And yet packets are just scrolling and
scrolling by, right?

69
00:03:30.140 --> 00:03:31.283
There's broadcast going.

70
00:03:31.283 --> 00:03:32.781
There's ARP resolution requests.

71
00:03:32.781 --> 00:03:35.030
There's DNS resolution requests.

72
00:03:35.030 --> 00:03:36.637
All kinds of things are happening.

73
00:03:36.637 --> 00:03:39.689
Two or three or five, ten nodes,
not that big of deal.

74
00:03:39.689 --> 00:03:43.868
200 nodes all doing those broadcasts
at the same time on the same LAN,

75
00:03:43.868 --> 00:03:46.830
everybody gets to hear it,
it becomes very noisy.

76
00:03:46.830 --> 00:03:51.480
We saturate our network, our local area
network, with this broadcast traffic.

77
00:03:51.480 --> 00:03:52.650
So what do we do?

78
00:03:52.650 --> 00:03:53.760
Well, we divide it up.

79
00:03:53.760 --> 00:03:57.570
We break that LAN up into
smaller little chunks, right?

80
00:03:57.570 --> 00:03:59.710
We take that room of 200 people and
say hey,

81
00:03:59.710 --> 00:04:03.730
you 20 people that are dealing with this,
go over here in this room, right?

82
00:04:03.730 --> 00:04:05.880
You guys, go over to this room.

83
00:04:05.880 --> 00:04:08.970
Same thing we can do with
our local area networks.

84
00:04:08.970 --> 00:04:11.840
We can divide them up
into smaller chunks so

85
00:04:11.840 --> 00:04:16.310
that you're only competing with the fewer
number of nodes instead of everybody.

86
00:04:16.310 --> 00:04:18.430
Like what Daniel said in
the beginning was a great example.

87
00:04:18.430 --> 00:04:23.770
You got your sales department, let's make
them their own little subnet, right?

88
00:04:23.770 --> 00:04:27.330
Let's take that RND and
make it a different subnet.

89
00:04:27.330 --> 00:04:30.810
So it helps reduce that
broadcast traffic and,

90
00:04:30.810 --> 00:04:33.570
as Daniel said,
it's a security thing, right?

91
00:04:33.570 --> 00:04:38.270
Because now, if I've got two different
subnets there, I can control access.

92
00:04:38.270 --> 00:04:41.590
I can say no, this computer's
with this range of IP addresses,

93
00:04:41.590 --> 00:04:43.850
it's not allowed to go
over to this subnet.

94
00:04:43.850 --> 00:04:44.630
There's no need for

95
00:04:44.630 --> 00:04:50.180
them to connect them to those file servers
over there on the RND network, all right?

96
00:04:50.180 --> 00:04:55.740
So, that's the issue we have with LANs and
how we deal with it, we break it up.

97
00:04:55.740 --> 00:04:56.710
How do we do that?

98
00:04:56.710 --> 00:04:59.260
How do we break it up into
those smaller chunks?

99
00:04:59.260 --> 00:05:01.410
Well, we can use routers, right?

100
00:05:01.410 --> 00:05:04.040
Routers route between networks.

101
00:05:04.040 --> 00:05:08.010
So I can create multiple subnets
on my local area network

102
00:05:08.010 --> 00:05:10.200
I put routers in between them, and

103
00:05:10.200 --> 00:05:14.720
now they can control the traffic that's
flowing between those different subnets.

104
00:05:14.720 --> 00:05:16.610
If I wanna allow access, I can.

105
00:05:16.610 --> 00:05:19.790
Like Daniel said,
have a subnet just for your servers and

106
00:05:19.790 --> 00:05:23.160
all your data, another subnet for
the sales department,

107
00:05:23.160 --> 00:05:28.470
another subnet for RND or HR or
accounting or what have you.

108
00:05:28.470 --> 00:05:30.410
We can divide it all up.

109
00:05:30.410 --> 00:05:34.460
But when we do it that way,
we've got routers to deal with now.

110
00:05:34.460 --> 00:05:38.140
So we have to start plopping routers down
in between all these different subnets.

111
00:05:38.140 --> 00:05:42.630
And routers can generate a little bit
of an issue as well when it comes to

112
00:05:42.630 --> 00:05:43.910
management, right?

113
00:05:43.910 --> 00:05:47.080
I've gotta have somebody familiar
with setting up a router,

114
00:05:47.080 --> 00:05:50.030
setting up those access control list and
controlling that traffic.

115
00:05:51.260 --> 00:05:55.800
Routers have routing tables that
they keep track of so they know

116
00:05:55.800 --> 00:05:59.950
where the different networks are, so
they can route the packets accordingly.

117
00:05:59.950 --> 00:06:02.010
Well, they have to share that information,
so

118
00:06:02.010 --> 00:06:07.490
we have routing protocols now on our
network that's taking up bandwidth.

119
00:06:07.490 --> 00:06:10.900
And depending on what routing protocol
you're using, like some of those internal

120
00:06:10.900 --> 00:06:14.402
protocols, they periodically just
broadcast out their routing tables.

121
00:06:14.402 --> 00:06:16.670
So we end up generating more traffic.

122
00:06:16.670 --> 00:06:18.680
We're putting overhead on there,

123
00:06:18.680 --> 00:06:24.110
when we're trying to simplify them and
ease that administration.

124
00:06:24.110 --> 00:06:28.815
And if you start moving computers between
subnets with routers, that might involve

125
00:06:28.815 --> 00:06:33.586
updating routing tables, updating rules,
access control lists on those routers,

126
00:06:33.586 --> 00:06:37.387
to make sure that they still have

I didn't ask for that.

577
00:31:19.340 --> 00:31:23.130
Oh wait, 12345,
that's this guy right here.

578
00:31:23.130 --> 00:31:29.040
So now I can take my IP address off of
there, I can your IP address back on.

579
00:31:31.995 --> 00:31:36.985
And now the packet can successfully
travel back over here to the requester

580
00:31:36.985 --> 00:31:38.570
of that data.

581
00:31:38.570 --> 00:31:40.859
So that is network address translation.

582
00:31:40.859 --> 00:31:45.745
We're temporarily translating that address
from a internal non-routable private

583
00:31:45.745 --> 00:31:50.506
IP address into a public address that can
be Transmitted out there on the Internet.

584
00:31:50.506 --> 00:31:51.552
And then, when it comes back,

585
00:31:51.552 --> 00:31:54.740
we're swapping them back around, and
putting that private IP address on.

586
00:31:54.740 --> 00:31:58.430
And we get back to the destination,
to that original center.

587
00:31:58.430 --> 00:32:01.220
Now, there's two different
ways we can do NAT.

588
00:32:01.220 --> 00:32:04.080
There's the dynamic NAT and
there's static NAT.

589
00:32:04.080 --> 00:32:05.330
In this case,

590
00:32:05.330 --> 00:32:10.000
I'm doing what's called dynamic NAT and
I only had one IP address to choose from.

591
00:32:10.000 --> 00:32:13.940
Dynamic NAT means that the NAT
device has a pool of addresses and

592
00:32:13.940 --> 00:32:15.750
it doesn't matter which one it uses.

593
00:32:15.750 --> 00:32:21.520
This computer didn't care that he changed
it to 12.2.4.50 on the way out and

594
00:32:21.520 --> 00:32:22.150
on the way back.

595
00:32:22.150 --> 00:32:25.430
As long as he gets his packet he's okay,
all right?

596
00:32:25.430 --> 00:32:28.072
So, the NAT device can use this.

597
00:32:28.072 --> 00:32:31.670
And this NAT device,
if I've got a busy network, he might

598
00:32:31.670 --> 00:32:36.670
have more than one public IP address
that he's allowed to use, all right?

599
00:32:36.670 --> 00:32:39.420
He might have a stack of
addresses that he can use.

600
00:32:42.994 --> 00:32:44.730
And he just picks one from the pool.

601
00:32:44.730 --> 00:32:46.530
That's dynamic NAT.

602
00:32:46.530 --> 00:32:50.790
Static NAT, for every internal device
that has a private IP address,

603
00:32:50.790 --> 00:32:54.230
there's gonna be a public
address out here.

604
00:32:54.230 --> 00:33:00.280
So, when this guy comes through,
it only uses this one IP address.

605
00:33:00.280 --> 00:33:04.221
You don't see it as often, because in that
case I would have to have a public IP

606
00:33:04.221 --> 00:33:08.118
address for every single machine that
I had in my internal network, right?

607
00:33:08.118 --> 00:33:12.308
And that's one of the beauties of this
NAT is, instead of having to go out and

608
00:33:12.308 --> 00:33:16.890
purchase public IP addresses for
every single machine, I can have three.

609
00:33:16.890 --> 00:33:21.000
Even though I've got 3,000 clients,
I only have 3 public IP addresses.

610
00:33:21.000 --> 00:33:23.700
And I can just use them temporarily
as that traffic goes out.

611
00:33:23.700 --> 00:33:27.360
The static NAT, you got addresses
that are assigned to those internal.

612
00:33:27.360 --> 00:33:31.150
A lot of times what you'll see with
static NAT is out in your DMZ.

613
00:33:31.150 --> 00:33:35.090
The web server might be statically
NATed for when it needs to go out and

614
00:33:35.090 --> 00:33:39.480
talk to the Internet and
it always uses the same public IP address.

615
00:33:40.980 --> 00:33:44.402
All right, so that's NAT, and Daniel I'll
tell you that, that's probably good.

616
00:33:44.402 --> 00:33:47.340
I know some other isolation
techniques that they mentioned,

617
00:33:47.340 --> 00:33:51.490
we've already talked about in
other episodes in this series.

618
00:33:51.490 --> 00:33:53.398
VPNs would be one, right?

619
00:33:53.398 --> 00:33:54.724
A virtual private network,

620
00:33:54.724 --> 00:33:59.555
you're isolating your VPN traffic from the
Internet by using that tunneling protocol.

621
00:33:59.555 --> 00:34:02.595
IPsec is another way you
can isolate traffic.

622
00:34:02.595 --> 00:34:07.666
It encrypts the traffic, I can isolate
it from the rest of my network outside.

623
00:34:07.666 --> 00:34:13.660
We can do IPsec VPN tunnels or we can do
site to site IPsec tunnels to isolate it.

624
00:34:13.660 --> 00:34:15.540
We can also do that internally, right?

625
00:34:15.540 --> 00:34:20.550
We can do server isolation and
domain isolation with IPsec.

626
00:34:20.550 --> 00:34:22.900
If I set up an IPsec policy that says,
hey,

627
00:34:22.900 --> 00:34:28.150
you have to have a certificate issued by
my company's certificate of authority

628
00:34:28.150 --> 00:34:31.170
in order to communicate with these guys,
then if you're from the outside and

629
00:34:31.170 --> 00:34:33.570
you don't have one of those certificates,
you don't talk.

630
00:34:33.570 --> 00:34:35.100
You're isolated.

631
00:34:35.100 --> 00:34:37.985
We can use isolation with
certificates like that,

632
00:34:37.985 --> 00:34:39.740
cuz also do it with [INAUDIBLE].

633
00:34:39.740 --> 00:34:42.923
If you're not a member of my domain,
if your computer doesn't have an account

634
00:34:42.923 --> 00:34:46.410
active directory, you don't get to talk to
any of the servers in my network, right?

635
00:34:46.410 --> 00:34:48.620
We're doing that domain isolation.

636
00:34:48.620 --> 00:34:52.682
So, may different isolation techniques
Daniel we can end up using to try to keep

637
00:34:52.682 --> 00:34:55.785
our traffic and
our network safe from unauthorized access.

638
00:34:55.785 --> 00:34:56.370
>> And that's right.

639
00:34:56.370 --> 00:34:58.420
And a little bit of
optimization in there as well.

640
00:34:58.420 --> 00:34:59.589
Throw that on as a kicker, right Mike?

641
00:34:59.589 --> 00:35:00.671
>> Yeah, absolutely.
>> [LAUGH]

642
00:35:00.671 --> 00:35:01.430
>> All right, Mike.

643
00:35:01.430 --> 00:35:03.865
Thank you so much for
those cool demonstrations and

644
00:35:03.865 --> 00:35:05.232
techniques that we can use.

645
00:35:05.232 --> 00:35:07.866
Segregate our traffic, gain that security,

646
00:35:07.866 --> 00:35:10.970
gain that optimization
throughout our network.

647
00:35:10.970 --> 00:35:13.830
That being said, looks like we've come to
the end of yet another awesome episode.

648
00:35:13.830 --> 00:35:15.390
Hopefully, you guys have enjoyed it.

649
00:35:15.390 --> 00:35:16.570
Thank you so much for watching.

650
00:35:16.570 --> 00:35:19.920
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowry.

651
00:35:19.920 --> 00:35:20.780
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

652
00:35:20.780 --> 00:35:23.094
>> And we'll see you next time.

653
00:35:23.094 --> 00:35:29.060
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel explore common protocol security concepts and methodologies. They start by explaining some of the common attack methods like Denial of Service, protocol spoofing, man-in-the-middle, network sniffing, and DNS poisoning, then moving into how you can protect your systems against those attacks using methods like Tunneling, IPSec, and DNSsec.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.726 --> 00:00:10.726
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.778 --> 00:00:13.345
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:13.345 --> 00:00:16.398
Welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.398 --> 00:00:18.004
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,

5
00:00:18.004 --> 00:00:21.285
joining me in the studio today
is none other than Mike Rodrick.

6
00:00:21.285 --> 00:00:22.600
How's it going today Mike?

7
00:00:22.600 --> 00:00:23.770
>> Oh, it's going great Daniel.

8
00:00:23.770 --> 00:00:24.830
I'm excited as always.

9
00:00:24.830 --> 00:00:28.390
We're doing more of our MTA content and
our security fundamentals.

10
00:00:28.390 --> 00:00:31.600
In this episode we're gonna be
looking at protocol security.

11
00:00:31.600 --> 00:00:33.130
Protocols being those languages or

12
00:00:33.130 --> 00:00:36.740
those set of rules that we use to
communicate across our network.

13
00:00:36.740 --> 00:00:39.950
And sometimes those can be abused,
misused, and

14
00:00:39.950 --> 00:00:41.920
can lead to some vulnerabilities.

15
00:00:41.920 --> 00:00:44.085
>> That's right.
So we've gotta take some countermeasures.

16
00:00:44.085 --> 00:00:47.260
We gotta do what we can
to secure them up so

17
00:00:47.260 --> 00:00:52.220
that people cannot continue to abuse or
misuse those set protocols.

18
00:00:52.220 --> 00:00:55.324
Now Mike, I know there are many ways in
which these things can be done because

19
00:00:55.324 --> 00:00:57.378
there's so
many different protocols out there.

20
00:00:57.378 --> 00:00:58.190
>> Yeah.

21
00:00:58.190 --> 00:01:00.305
>> So there's a lot of different
attack venues in which they can come

22
00:01:00.305 --> 00:01:00.848
at you, right?

23
00:01:00.848 --> 00:01:02.056
>> There really are.

24
00:01:02.056 --> 00:01:06.919
Probably one of the first ones we should
start with or the one that you've heard of

25
00:01:06.919 --> 00:01:10.137
out there in TV land,
is gonna be a denial of service or

26
00:01:10.137 --> 00:01:14.094
what's called a distributed
denial of service, DOS, or DDOS.

27
00:01:14.094 --> 00:01:17.650
And what that means is we're going
to try to overload a protocol.

28
00:01:17.650 --> 00:01:23.640
We're gonna try to make it so busy that it
can't do what it's supposed to do, right?

29
00:01:23.640 --> 00:01:27.303
So if I say I want to do a denial of
service, say, on a web server, well,

30
00:01:27.303 --> 00:01:28.600
what's a web server do?

31
00:01:28.600 --> 00:01:33.140
A web server listens on port 80 and
it waits for HTTP get request.

32
00:01:33.140 --> 00:01:37.580
People wanting a web page to be
delivered to their browser on their end.

33
00:01:37.580 --> 00:01:41.935
So what I can do, is I can send request
after request after request after request

34
00:01:41.935 --> 00:01:46.302
and try to send so many that that web
server just says, I can't keep up, right?

35
00:01:46.302 --> 00:01:51.283
And all of a sudden, I got people that
are legitimate customers trying to get to

36
00:01:51.283 --> 00:01:53.246
my webpage to buy my product and

37
00:01:53.246 --> 00:01:57.200
they can't because my web
server's too darnn busy, right?

38
00:01:57.200 --> 00:02:01.662
Now, that's a denial of service attack and
it can be done on other protocols as well.

39
00:02:01.662 --> 00:02:02.710
That was just one example.

40
00:02:02.710 --> 00:02:05.960
A distributive denial of
service just means I'm going to

41
00:02:05.960 --> 00:02:07.090
step it up a notch, right?

42
00:02:07.090 --> 00:02:10.390
We're gonna throw in more attackers.

43
00:02:10.390 --> 00:02:13.200
When if I was trying to attack a website,
right?

44
00:02:13.200 --> 00:02:17.160
These websites nowadays it's not like,
depending, if it's a large organization,

45
00:02:17.160 --> 00:02:18.470
they're got many web servers.

46
00:02:18.470 --> 00:02:20.610
They've got a farm that's
hosting this website,

47
00:02:20.610 --> 00:02:24.530
so if one of their servers fails,
people can still get to their webpage.

48
00:02:24.530 --> 00:02:25.440
So, now all of the sudden,

49
00:02:25.440 --> 00:02:29.560
my one little attack computer can't
do a denial of service against them.

50
00:02:29.560 --> 00:02:34.040
They've got more resources than I've got
available to try to launch this attack,

51
00:02:34.040 --> 00:02:35.550
so what do I do?

52
00:02:35.550 --> 00:02:37.200
I distribute the attack, right?

53
00:02:37.200 --> 00:02:40.320
I take 100 machines,
I take 1,000 machines, and

54
00:02:40.320 --> 00:02:42.070
I launch the attack from there.

55
00:02:42.070 --> 00:02:46.700
Now all of a sudden I've got enough power
to do an effective denial of service.

56
00:02:46.700 --> 00:02:49.151
So denial of service,
distributive denial of service,

57
00:02:49.151 --> 00:02:51.610
just means that I'm going to
distribute the attack out.

58
00:02:51.610 --> 00:02:56.229
This is where you hear terms like zombies,
or bot farms, or botnets.

59
00:02:56.229 --> 00:02:58.440
These are all machines that I can control.

60
00:02:58.440 --> 00:03:00.120
I've infected them already somehow.

61
00:03:00.120 --> 00:03:01.400
I've taken them over.

62
00:03:01.400 --> 00:03:05.100
And when I click launch on my computer,
it's not launching the attack.

63
00:03:05.100 --> 00:03:07.490
It's sending out the attack
signal to all those bots and

64
00:03:07.490 --> 00:03:09.170
then they all attack at once.

65
00:03:09.170 --> 00:03:12.077
So you've got denial of service,
you've got distributed denial of service.

66
00:03:13.560 --> 00:03:16.240
Some other types of attacks
are spoofing attacks.

67
00:03:16.240 --> 00:03:18.720
And these can be done at
different protocols as well.

68
00:03:18.720 --> 00:03:23.898
We've got IP spoofing, we've got ARP
spoofing, we've got DNS spoofing.

69
00:03:23.898 --> 00:03:28.109
And spoofing, Daniel,
as we've said earlier,

70
00:03:28.109 --> 00:03:32.431
it's just pretending to
be something else right?

71
00:03:32.431 --> 00:03:35.080
>> Yeah,
you're blocking these IP addresses right?

72
00:03:35.080 --> 00:03:37.462
Well, I know that those IP
addresses are being blocked.

73
00:03:37.462 --> 00:03:40.170
I'm gonna find a range of IP addresses
that aren't being blocked, and

74
00:03:40.170 --> 00:03:42.810
I'm gonna pretend that
that's my IP address.

75
00:03:42.810 --> 00:03:46.630
The same with a lot of different
protocols, basically the same idea.

76
00:03:46.630 --> 00:03:49.860
I'm going to wrap around my real

77
00:03:49.860 --> 00:03:54.220
IP address with a fake one that says,
oh, I'm trusted.

78
00:03:54.220 --> 00:03:55.950
You can trust me.

79
00:03:55.950 --> 00:03:58.420
I'm something you wanna allow through.

80
00:03:58.420 --> 00:04:00.460
The firewalls, take a look at that.

81
00:04:00.460 --> 00:04:01.906
All the security measures
we take a look at.

82
00:04:01.906 --> 00:04:06.195
We'll look at that and go, oh yeah,
yeah, that 1.2.5 address or

83
00:04:06.195 --> 00:04:08.490
whatever it is, is allowed through.

84
00:04:08.490 --> 00:04:09.740
So go ahead, come on in.

85
00:04:09.740 --> 00:04:11.245
You're on the list sir.

86
00:04:11.245 --> 00:04:13.850
>> [LAUGH]
>> And they allow that traffic.

87
00:04:13.850 --> 00:04:16.040
So that's a common way spoofing is done.

88
00:04:16.040 --> 00:04:18.920
>> It is, and a lot of times it
leads to other types of attacks.

89
00:04:18.920 --> 00:04:21.040
So what I'm gonna do is, I'm gonna
open up a command prompt here and

90
00:04:21.040 --> 00:04:23.200
take a look at my ARP cache.

91
00:04:23.200 --> 00:04:25.858
I'll do a little arp -a.

92
00:04:25.858 --> 00:04:30.074
And what's happening here is,
my machine is trying to deliver a packet,

93
00:04:30.074 --> 00:04:34.089
say trying to connect to 201, and
it needs that physical address.

94
00:04:34.089 --> 00:04:39.812
So again, IP calls ARP, ARP resolves
that IP address into a MAC address.

95
00:04:39.812 --> 00:04:44.050
Now my machine can connect or
deliver that data.

96
00:04:44.050 --> 00:04:46.930
For example, you don't see 101 in here.

97
00:04:46.930 --> 00:04:51.027
By pinging svr01,
it'll ping that IP address.

98
00:04:51.027 --> 00:04:55.258
If I now look at my cache,
I'll see that 101

99
00:04:55.258 --> 00:04:59.910
has now been turned into a MAC address,
right?

100
00:04:59.910 --> 00:05:03.150
So in order to deliver that packet,
that ping packet,

101
00:05:03.150 --> 00:05:06.690
my computer knows the IP address that
he wants to send that packet to.

102
00:05:06.690 --> 00:05:10.528
But in order to finish the process, it has
to turn the IP address into a MAC address.

103
00:05:10.528 --> 00:05:15.370
So, IP calls ARP, ARP resolves it
into a MAC address and now it can go.

104
00:05:15.370 --> 00:05:18.323
But notice I cache the response and
that's really what I wanted to show you,

105
00:05:18.323 --> 00:05:19.719
was that I've got this cache here.

106
00:05:19.719 --> 00:05:23.988
So the next time my computer
needs to talk to 101, 10.1.1.101,

107
00:05:23.988 --> 00:05:26.140
he already knows the MAC address.

108
00:05:26.140 --> 00:05:27.360
It doesn't even have to bother.

109
00:05:27.360 --> 00:05:29.560
And this is a type of attack we can do.

110
00:05:29.560 --> 00:05:33.430
I can insert bad data into your ARP cache.

111
00:05:33.430 --> 00:05:34.870
I can attempt to do that.

112
00:05:34.870 --> 00:05:37.760
And I can redirect traffic, right?

113
00:05:37.760 --> 00:05:39.573
Your computer says, oh,
I need to connect to 101.

114
00:05:39.573 --> 00:05:42.510
But what if this was
the bad guy's MAC address?

115
00:05:42.510 --> 00:05:44.560
What if he put bad information in there?

116
00:05:44.560 --> 00:05:45.878
Your computer wouldn't know any better.

117
00:05:45.878 --> 00:05:50.547
It would say I already know the MAC
address for 10.1.1.101, here it is,

118
00:05:50.547 --> 00:05:54.562
I'll go ahead and put that in my
packet and send it on it's way, right?

119
00:05:54.562 --> 00:05:58.696
That would be what's called ARP poisoning,
if I can say that.

120
00:05:58.696 --> 00:06:03.290
And now this is the first step in what
we call a man in the middle attack.

121
00:06:03.290 --> 00:06:04.730
>> Yeah, very, very common and

122
00:06:04.730 --> 00:06:08.420
dangerous type of attack, because what
it does is it says, well, guess what?

123
00:06:08.420 --> 00:06:10.360
That ARP you were looking for?

124
00:06:10.360 --> 00:06:11.030
That's me.

125
00:06:11.030 --> 00:06:14.770
So, if you need to send packets to that IP
address, I'm the ARP you're looking for.

126
00:06:14.770 --> 00:06:17.630
And then it tells the machine
that it actually was looking for,

127
00:06:17.630 --> 00:06:19.010
you know that guy that's
trying to send you?

128
00:06:19.010 --> 00:06:23.860
Well, that's actually me, and poisons his
ARP table like what Mike's showing you.

129
00:06:23.860 --> 00:06:27.330
So, both of those devices start
sending all the data that's meant for

130
00:06:27.330 --> 00:06:29.990
each other to that guy in the middle.

131
00:06:29.990 --> 00:06:31.790
And then he sends it on the way.

132
00:06:31.790 --> 00:06:35.200
But, while he sits in the middle, he can
take a look, oh, that's nice information.

133
00:06:35.200 --> 00:06:36.650
Oh, what's on this sheet of paper?

134
00:06:36.650 --> 00:06:37.858
As he passes it along.

135
00:06:37.858 --> 00:06:39.530
He sits in the middle and
he can capture data.

136
00:06:39.530 --> 00:06:41.330
It's a very dangerous attack.

137
00:06:41.330 --> 00:06:42.030
>> It is and

138
00:06:42.030 --> 00:06:46.670
sometimes it can be really difficult
to detect that it's even going on.

139
00:06:46.670 --> 00:06:49.330
DNS spoofing is another one we can do.

140
00:06:49.330 --> 00:06:51.620
DNS being our name resolution protocol.

141
00:06:51.620 --> 00:06:54.703
Your computer, when you type in a name,
like I did just a minute ago.

142
00:06:54.703 --> 00:06:57.470
I typed in srv01, I tried to ping that.

143
00:06:57.470 --> 00:07:00.930
Well computers can't connect to names,
they can only connect to IP addresses.

144
00:07:00.930 --> 00:07:02.650
So my computer called up DNS and

145
00:07:02.650 --> 00:07:08.150
said hey, my user wants to send a packet
to svr01, what's its IP address?

146
00:07:08.150 --> 00:07:10.550
DNS responded with that IP address.

147
00:07:10.550 --> 00:07:15.170
That information gets cached as well,
both on the client end and the server end.

148

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike describe common methods for implementing client and server protection. They start with client protection through User Account Controls(UAC), system updates, and software restrictions. They then move to server hardening through network isolation, disabling insecure protocols, and checking for security vulnerabilities using the Microsoft Baseline Security Analyzer(MBSA).
